name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 4 April 2019.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before resuming work, I would like to express my deep concern at the 38-year prison sentence and 148 frustrated sentences of Iranian lawyer Nasrin Sotoudeh, winner of the 2012 Sakharov Prize. His only fault is to fight for the defence of human rights in Iran. On behalf of the European Parliament, I strongly condemn this absurd judgment and believe that all of you agree with me in calling for Nasrin's immediate release. I would also like to express my condolences to the families of the 76 victims of the floods in Iran in recent weeks. The European Union stands ready to provide humanitarian aid to deal with the emergency.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this is an essential debate for the European citizens we have this afternoon, because it is about recognising the essential role that whistleblowers play in our democracies, placing our demands for transparency and good governance above economic and financial powers and, above all, ensuring, as a fair return, of things. , the protection of those who have the courage to protect our general interest, of those who have the courage to speak to protect us. The aim is to make the European Union one of the most advanced policy spaces for whistleblower protection. This directive is the result of a long process, in particular by this Parliament, which since 2014 has highlighted in its work the importance of effective protection of whistleblowers, before expressing very clearly, on several occasions, its formal request for a directive. Since the beginning of the mandate, scandals have accumulated: LuxLeaks, Panama Papers, Football Leaks. They have shed a harsh light on the very precarious situation faced by whistleblowers. Then the directive on business secrecy arrived. There has been a great deal of concern, which we have tried to correct in the directive, but above all we have conditioned the vote on this directive on the establishment of genuine European protection for whistleblowers. I remember very well the debates that took place in 2016 in this Chamber, where we were told that this was not possible, that there was not sufficient legal basis in the treaties to enable the European Union to act. And yet, today, three years later, we are debating this issue before adopting tomorrow - I hope - a directive that will protect whistleblowers throughout the Union. The commitment of parliamentarians, as well as that of civil society and NGOs that I want to welcome here, is therefore bearing fruit. It moves the lines and encourages Europe to listen to the concerns of European citizens. This is not so common on my part, but I would like to stress this here today: I would like to congratulate Commissioner Jourova for her commitment and the European Commission for the inventiveness it has shown to finally dispel the difficulties that were against us and to find a solution to put in place a European protection for whistleblowers. So today we have this text which will provide the widest possible protection, as Parliament called for in the initiative report voted in 2017. Of course, as part of this protection, employees who are in a traditional working relationship will be covered, but also consultants, trainees, contractors, service providers and independent experts. We wanted not to leave a void in the protection we put in place. Similarly, we wanted to be able to protect those accompanying whistleblowers - facilitators, colleagues, whistleblower relatives - who may also be involved or affected by reprisals. I am also pleased that we have managed in these negotiations to preserve the original ambition, which was already in the Commission's proposal, to cover as wide a scope as possible, ranging from the protection of the Financial Interests of the European Union, to corporate tax issues, to environmental protection. I hope that the Member States will be keen to follow a common recommendation and go beyond the sectoral scope defined in the directive to ensure the widest possible horizontal transposition. The reporting mechanisms that we have put in place are strong and they are also there to change attitudes. This was an essential point, which translates into the obligation to set up internal channels within the company. But I am pleased that we have returned to the obligation, initially planned, to go through an internal report in the first place. I believe that this was one of the major problems of the original proposal of the text and, on this point, the European Parliament has fully played its role as co-legislator by making these improvements and by blowing up this obligation which would inevitably have exposed the whistleblower to reprisals. Finally, this text proposes really effective protections against reprisals: immunity from confidentiality clauses and business secrecy, immunity also with regard to the acquisition of the revealed information, protection that had to be negotiated hard with some of the Member States, and then the reversal of the burden of proof. labour disputes, which will effectively protect employees. The obligations of information and support, including psychological and financial, are strengthened so as not to leave alone those people who often find themselves very isolated in the face of gigantic multinationals. On the whole, therefore, it is a very ambitious text that we are about to adopt and which responds to the challenge posed to our democracies. I would like to thank my colleagues, the shadow rapporteurs, who have been heavily involved in this matter and have shown that when Parliament is united, it succeeds in producing results, it even manages to overthrow blocking minorities in the Council, which is not so common. And I would like to thank the Romanian Presidency, which, through its decisive action on this issue, through its leadership, has produced this excellent result, and also renew my thanks to Commissioner Jourova, who has shown a great spirit of compromise on this directive. I thank you all and I hope that the vote tomorrow will materialis this progress for the European Union.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: rapporteur of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Madam President, I was in charge of drawing up the opinion of the LIBE Commission. Although it was just an opinion, the shadow opinion speakers and myself wanted to do a comprehensive job, dealing with the entire legislative proposal and going beyond what the European Commission presented in April last year. The JURI Commission helped us to propose Parliament's position according to what society needs and demands. We have managed to tackle the fragmentation of whistleblower protection in the European Union, increasing legal certainty. Today, whistleblowers continue to be silenced and often dare not communicate for fear of reprisals, but with this directive we hope to have started to succeed so that they are protected by secure reporting channels. We also protect the sources of investigative journalism. We protect the civic duty to denounce, so that it is not an act of heroism. An extra layer of safeguarding of the public interest is added, because the work of the PANA Committee of Inquiry in this Parliament would not have been possible without Panama's papers. And fortunately, John Doe managed to save his anonymity. They are the guts of great tax evasions, of the great crimes that weaken our democracy and public coffers. That is why our aim is to protect the general good, and with this directive we all win. I hope we got it right!

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start by thanking the rapporteur, Ms Virginie Rozière, the shadow rapporteurs and the Council Presidencies for the hard work accomplished which allowed for swift agreement on this important proposal. Yes, I agree with the rapporteur, the negotiations were not easy, but we all knew that we were working on something very, very important, and the Commission considers the agreement reached is a well-balanced compromise, both in terms of ensuring robust protection for whistle-blowers and in strengthening the enforcement of EU law. Recent scandals such as ‘dieselgate’, LuxLeaks, the Panama Papers or Cambridge Analytica, would not have come to light without the courage of whistle-blowers. By protecting whistle-blowers through these rules, we can better detect and prevent harm to the public interest such as fraud, corruption, corporate tax avoidance and damage to people’s health or the environment. This compromise ensures high standards of protection, widely available reporting channels and a broad, personal and material scope. Whistle-blowers are encouraged to use the internal channel first where the breach can be effectively addressed within the organisation they work for. The availability of easily accessible internal channels, both in the public and the private sector and in all companies with 50 or more employees, will provide this possibility to whistle-blowers. But – and I know this was an important issue for this House – whistle-blowers will also have the free choice to report directly to the competent authorities as they see fit in light of the circumstances of the case. They will be fully protected when doing so. The broad material scope guarantees that the directive will strengthen enforcement in key areas of EU law and policies. This gives effect to the Commission’s commitment to put stronger focus on enforcement to serve the general interest, as set out in its 2016 Communication on EU law: Better results through better application. Moreover, as this is a directive with common minimum standards, the Commission encourages the Member States to extend the directive’s rules to other areas and to establish comprehensive frameworks for whistle-blower protection. This possibility for Member States is now explicitly reflected in that text. As part of the compromise on the material scope we foresee a review of the implementation of the directive at the earliest possible time. That means in 2025, four years after the transposition of the directive and, in this context, to assess specifically the issue of including the social policy area in the material scope of the directive. This would allow for an in-depth assessment of how the directive would interact with the existing social acquis. Accordingly, the Commission will make the following political declaration to be annexed to the directive: ‘At the time of the review to be conducted in accordance with Article 27 of the directive, the Commission will consider the possibility of proposing to extend its scope of application to certain acts based on Articles 153 and 157 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union after consulting the social partners, where appropriate, in accordance with Article 154.’ (End of quote.) To conclude, by agreeing on these standards the EU is demonstrating its commitment to transparency, good governance, accountability and freedom of expression which are values and rights on which the EU is based, and this is a clear and important signal that we are sending to the citizens and stakeholders on the eve of the European elections. The Commission fully supports the compromise found by the co-legislators and looks forward to tomorrow’s vote.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: rapporteur for the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Madam President, whistle—blowers are extraordinary people. They’re brave people. They take massive risks. What we’ve done here today hopefully means that you won’t have to be an extraordinarily brave person to become a whistle—blower because, at the moment, in my country, if you become a whistle—blower, you are right to be afraid. You will be mentally tortured, you will be financially destroyed, and you will probably never ever work again. What we’ve got to do is create a situation where absolutely everyone has zero fear about reporting wrongdoing and that, when they do, they will not be the people who end up with the whistle stuck in their throat, not able to breathe, not able to exist, not able to live. So I think we’ve done something good here today. That doesn’t always happen, so I clap for that.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Madam President, since the 'business secret' directive does not create the conditions for effective security for whistleblowers, it is time to strengthen the text, as the rapporteur, Mrs Rozière, rightly proposes. This is in the public interest: it is therefore right that the protection should be total, the scope of the application to be as broad as possible and to suffer only from well-defined exceptions. States will, however, have a great deal of leeway in the implementation of this directive, which may be a cause for concern, given the attempts by some governments to block it. Thus, in the absence of a European whistleblower protection authority, as my group requested, the Commission will have to ensure that the protections we create are properly and strictly enforced, for example by following up on the application of this text by guidelines you have referred to, Commissioner, or by interpretive communication to ensure that all Europeans have the same maximum protection when they want to report practices contrary to the general interest. I would add that now is the time to create the conditions to protect Julian Assange, to whom the rights of journalists must apply under the European Convention on Human Rights.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Madam President, Commissioner, you say you want to protect whistleblowers. Very well. But who comes to Julian Assange's rescue? The honour of the Europeans would be to acknowledge the debt we owe to him, for it was Julian Assange, let us never forget, who revealed the massive spying by the United States on Allied European countries. Our duty today is to grant him asylum, since, as you know, he is in danger of being extradited. By inflicting such treatment on it, it is all whistleblowers, whom our regulations want to protect, that we are actually trying to terrorize. The time has come to change the fear of camp and to protect those who are hunted down, harassed, brought to justice, tried, sometimes even murdered, pay a high price for the service rendered to the public interest and this begins with the immediate release of Julian Assange.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: draftsman of the opinion of the CULT Committee. – Madam President, the arrest of Julian Assange is an image of our future; a future of freedom and repression, where any revelation of the barbarity and illegalities of neoliberal totalitarianism will be considered a crime by the governments of the Western world. The arrest of Assange by the British Government — at the behest of the United States — was made because the WikiLeaks website revealed the barbarity of the interventions of the United States and its allies in the Middle East and elsewhere, as well as the violation of human rights and international law. This is how imperialist forces treat freedom of expression and militant journalism that reveals their darkest sides in the interests of democracy, transparency and truth. The Assange arrest concerns us all. We must protect those who stand up for political and economic power. If we want a different future for Europe, a different future for our world, we must join forces with the movement to defend freedoms of expression and information.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Madam President, I do indeed believe that today we are going to take a big step in favour of transparency, in the public interest and also in eu law. I would add that we take a big step also in favor of ethics: ethics in business, ethics in public activity.  I would like to congratulate Virginie Roziére on her great work; also to the commissioner.  I would like to say, ladies and gentlemen, that whistleblowers are not criminals; I think they're rather exemplary citizens. And unfortunately, we have many, many examples that they have suffered brutal repression, lost their jobs, lost their professional careers, been persecuted to their economic ruin and have even been criminally prosecuted for criminal law in some countries. And this can't be, this had to stop.  And fortunately, this directive , which is good, which I think is very comprehensive, as has been said, which favours, as has been shown, the opinion of all political groups — is a big step, and I only hope that governments will transpose the directive well and quickly.

name: Axel VOSS
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, thank you very much for the presentation. That, too, was basically time. It was a pity that this had to happen at the end of our parliamentary term under very time pressure. Perhaps we should take a little more time in this case. On behalf of our shadow rapporteur, Geoffroy Didier, I would also like to express my sincere thanks to the rapporteur, who has handled this pressure with a great deal of passion, and also the other rapporteurs. Accordingly, we now have a guide to legitimate whistleblowing. It was also time for us to set this up with the conditions that have already been mentioned. I also think it is good – and this is now also reflected in the compromise – that we must see the law as the basis of our coexistence and also assess what is lawful and what is illegal, and that we do not have to discuss moral or ethical matters there, but that here law really is the basis of everything. I also think it is good that we have found a reasonable basis for small and medium-sized enterprises here, because the implementation costs of companies are extremely high, and that we have also found a way here where we can reduce that, where we can join forces, perhaps set it up appropriately through the associations. And I also think it is good that we have found here a model of reporting that does not immediately go to the press, but also where we have to orientate ourselves on the fact that there are internal or even external possibilities to make sure again here. Thank you very much for your contribution to this. On the part of the Ppe-DE Group, I believe that we can support this well.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Today is a very special day for me: 28 years after I first entered the European Parliament as an observer for the new Länder, I have the honour of speaking for the last time in the plenary of this House.  I would like to take this opportunity to thank you and you very much! I have always enjoyed working with you, ladies and gentlemen, because it has always been about our common Europe. This Parliament, with Members from so many different countries, is truly unique. And we have really achieved a great deal – together. And we should never be deterred from fighting for this project. Nationalists and populists must never mispronounce or even destroy this common European project!  Tomorrow, we will give the green light to Europe-wide protection of whistleblowers, Europe-wide protection for people who expose abuses in the public interest – a great success for citizens and a great success for us MEPs. We have been calling for this protection for a very long time, and we have fought hard for it. And that paid off. I hope that many of the Members who are standing for re-election will communicate this example of whistleblower protection and many other positive examples from the everyday lives of our citizens, and above all combine this with a message: the European project offers added value for all citizens, and I am proud and happy that I have been able to work on it.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. – Dear Chairman, it is important that we discuss this proposal to protect whistleblowers precisely these days when Julien Assange was arrested and in the context of more frequent legal and physical attacks on journalists. I am particularly pleased that we have a balanced report in front of us that, after application, would improve the protection of all those who share hidden information, but of public interest. But for the protection system to work, we need to create social circumstances where whistleblowers' self-sacrifice is valued and institutions treat the information they have received transparently and professionally. This information should not be taken for granted because it would leave room for manipulation of the public, but it would certainly have to be the basis for conducting an investigation and presenting the full truth.   Another important precondition is the effectiveness of the judiciary and the security apparatus, which is a pressing problem in several Member States that must be addressed as soon as possible.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, if we look back a little highly on this mandate, it will have brought the protection of personal data to European citizens and even provided the idea to American parliamentarians that they should draw inspiration from our work so that individuals are not the objects of digital, and in particular the oligopolies that are GAFA. If we also look at this session and this five-year term that has just passed, we will see today that fundamental work has just been done. If Mr. Snowden were European, he would not be exiled to a small Moscow dacha, under the supervision of all the intelligence services, a prey for all kinds of spies who want to see him extradited, sent back to the United States, where he would probably face the worst punishments. So, ladies and gentlemen, say around you when you are told about Europe, that not only is it a remarkable economic entity that has abolished borders, but above all it is an entity that has protected, more than any other continent in the world, individual freedoms and collective freedoms. It is in this capacity that I would like to thank two exceptional women for this work, Mrs Rozière, our rapporteur, who has conducted this work in a very masterful way, and Commissioner Jourova, whose text, while we always say so much bad of the Commission, was absolutely essential, since it was going in the right direction. Your work will mark with a blank stone that day when you have silenced all the critics of the Union and all those who would like to pay, to fold the European Union behind borders where no law would really be of value. Thank you and congratulations for this work.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, a Europe that protects the public interest, a Europe that protects the citizens of the Union as a whole is perfectly possible. There is no need to leave the treaties, there is no need to retreat within borders. On the contrary, this Europe exists! At a time when democracy is in danger, by opacity, by the technicality of a large number of new products, this Europe, this democracy, needs whistleblowers. It needs citizens who stand up and denounce facts that some would like to hide. That is what we are doing today, which is what the European Parliament has just done thanks to the Commission. Thank you, Mrs Jourova, thank you, Mr Timmermans, who wished to put this in place. Thanks also to Virginie Rozière and all those who worked on this file. But beyond the importance of this text, I want to remember one thing: when Parliament is united, when Parliament actually wants to defend the public interest, then nothing stops it - neither conservatism nor lobbies - and we can advance democracy and law.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have finally arrived at adopting a directive that the whole of Europe has been waiting for for years.  It is estimated that, between resources taken from taxation and missed foreign investment, corruption costs our Union as a whole some EUR 904 billion a year in gross domestic product and, despite this, even today, we did not have specific legislation to protect whistleblowers, precisely those who are always at the forefront of this fight. Among them are the best citizens of this Union, the best journalists who often go ahead with investigations just when they hear that they are about to rummage through the murky and bring out the truth.  We should be grateful to these people. We are all indebted to these people and it cannot be the case that they are marginalised by society. These people must be protected, because what happened to Daphne Caruana Galizia in 2017 and to Ján Kuciak in 2018 cannot and must never happen again. Indeed, this directive consistently provides for protection against any kind of retaliation by the complainants, for the whistleblower as well as for his family, and leaves it to the Member States to adopt even more advanced discipline than this minimum standard. It therefore seems paradoxical, ladies and gentlemen, that on the very eve of the adoption of this directive - and we will be discussing this tomorrow - Julian Assange, founder of WikiLeaks, is arrested in the United Kingdom. Assange should not be extradited to the US, where he risks the death penalty for his uncomfortable relations, not in my Europe.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as you know, transparency in political, institutional and economic behaviour and dynamics is essential to guarantee the general interest, and therefore to strengthen democracy.  What we are doing is a very important step in the right direction. The matter was a sensitive one, but we must thank these courageous people, the whistleblowers, who have exposed, over the last few months and years, completely negative facts such as LuxLeaks, panama paper, paradise paper, with the contradiction of working for them for general interests and being persecuted because nothing defended them. For this we must thank you, the rapporteur and all those who have worked with conviction. Thank you for what you have done and I hope that you will continue to give us practical help in applying it properly.

name: Julia REDA
text: – Madam President, almost three years ago the Verts/ALE Group presented a draft directive on whistle-blower protection. This draft was the result of a concerted effort from civil society, journalists and politicians, and it was a reaction to the Trade Secrets Directive that had just been adopted and has been a threat to whistle-blowers ever since. The draft we presented showed that EU action on whistle-blowers is possible. It coincided with the LuxLeaks trials, which showed more clearly than ever that such protection is also needed. One of our goals was to ensure that trade secrets cannot be weaponised against whistle-blowers, as was the case with LuxLeaks whistle-blower Antoine Deltour. In 2015 he was awarded the European Citizen’s Prize, but a year later a Luxembourg court found him guilty of disclosing trade secrets – a bogus charge that was meant to intimidate. The legal hoops he had to jump through for a court to dismiss this verdict were long and taxing. Now the Commission and the Parliament have really risen to the challenge. The draft directive we are about to adopt makes explicit what we demanded in 2016: that whistle-blower protection take precedence over trade secrets. With this directive, whistle-blowers like Antoine Deltour will finally be able to rely on EU protection, and I would like to thank the Commissioner, the rapporteur and all the colleagues who worked on this. It’s a great step forward for the European citizens.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Madam President, the European Union is, above all, a community of law and must therefore ensure that its own rules are respected if it is to function properly. I see the report presented as a means of ensuring respect for the law in a complex 21st century society. Experience shows us that it is in the general interest to provide protection to whistle-blowers who report breaches of European law. Unfortunately, it is clear that society cannot do without modern rules protecting whistleblowers. In some cases, the role of whistle-blowers can be crucial to detecting otherwise difficult-to-detect breaches. However, this must be a balanced protection, we are dealing with a similar issue of a useful level of protection here, as in the case of representative actions, for example. This is not a duel of interests of employees or employers, but it is good that some disagreements have been overcome during the negotiations and a good compromise has been reached, and I will therefore support this proposal.

text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Power needs control! The Whistleblower Directive makes a valuable contribution to this. Protecting courageous uncoverers acting in the public interest: that is what it is all about!  I would like to remind you of Antoine Deltour and Raphael Halet. These two are true heroes, and they have paid a very high price for it: remember, LuxLeaks was the trigger for uncovering the big tax scandals. I would therefore like to thank Virginie, iwould like to thank Mrs Jourov as Commissioner, but also to all the Members who have worked on this, because we have shown that we need a self-confident Parliament that works together and, in that respect, in fact takes the right of initiative.

name: Eva JOLY
text: Madam President, Commissioner, this directive for the protection of whistleblowers shows that it is possible to change Europe. This requires political will, optimism and hard work. No, Europe as it is is not the one that environmentalists dream of, but we are not giving up. The European Commission had said in 2015 that a text to protect whistleblowers was not possible to deal with constant treatment. We environmentalists have proven otherwise. We have drawn up our own directive to show Jean-Claude Juncker that treaties should not be an excuse for immobility. Protecting whistleblowers means protecting the essence of our democracies, defending the public interest rather than so-called trade secrets. It is thanks to courageous people, such as Antoine Deltour, who revealed the LuxLeaks, that our fight against tax evasion is progressing. Protecting whistleblowers is one of many victories that we have snatched from our tenacity. A victory particularly dear to my heart.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, do we all agree with the principle that those who act in the common interest deserve protection? If so, it is because we agree that the defence of the general interest of the community, of the common interest, calls on everyone without exception. But if so, why don't we all agree that so-called whistleblowers, if they act for the benefit of all, should deserve protection? No one questions whether a worker can report a violation of labour rights in the authority to protect working conditions. What distinguishes this worker from another worker who discovers, for example, that his company is easing away from taxes? Obviously, it's not worth everything in the name of common interest. Madam President, this is a reasonable text, which deserves our support and which defends the common interest.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, this directive is for transparency and integrity in the European Union, because whistleblowers are essential to dismantle crime that infiltrates businesses and captures administrations, governments and even justice bodies. It complements Article 38 of the fourth Anti-Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Directive, which already obliges Member States to set up protection mechanisms, even for whistleblowers with no direct employment relationship with organisations. name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to the rapporteur, Virginie Rozière. We called for minimum standards of protection for whistleblowers across Europe, with reliable channels and protection from whistleblowers and scandals, as was the case with LuxLeaks and the Panama Papers. They deserve full protection and not retaliation or even condemnation, because they protect the public interest, and tomorrow I hope that this House will give a signal of unity and strength.  I joined five years ago as a proud European federalist, and I am even more convinced of why our Union is so necessary to respond at the right level to the challenges facing us in the future.
