name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, we are discussing a very important issue, the protection of witnesses, who of course have the opportunity to inform the authorities and thus clarify the situation in cases of fraud, tax evasion and money laundering. This debate on complainants has taken place on several occasions, both here and in the Committee on Petitions, and I think that the steps we are taking are particularly important, because without the protection of these people, all the scandals that have taken place will not be revealed. We had the LuxLeaks problem, we had huge tax evasion, we had illegal operation of multinationals. All these functions and actions can only come to light and those responsible are punished by the public authorities if the complainants are protected. I consider our actions in this area to be important.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, the protection of whistleblowers is a serious but also sensitive issue. There is no doubt that anyone who denounces an act which harms the public interest, such as corruption, fraud, tax evasion, environmental pollution, breach of nuclear safety, etc., makes a decisive contribution not only to avoiding such illegal acts but also to making the rule of law work smoothly. That is why witnesses must be protected. Otherwise, if their identity is revealed, they risk becoming the subject of threats, attacks and — in any case — intimidation and will cease to report any illegality that comes to their attention from then on. However, care must be taken not to slander or blackmail protected witnesses, let them not be used as false witnesses in civil proceedings.  In view of the above, I believe that the report is moving in the right direction and we must support it.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Honourable Members for their interventions. I also would like to encourage you to vote in favour of the compromise reached on the proposal. Judging from your overall positive contributions here, I do hope that it will come true tomorrow. Then, indeed, as many of you mentioned here, we must concentrate our efforts on ensuring a full and correct transposition of the directive across all the Member States as soon as possible.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, thank you to all colleagues for their support, encouragement and repeated greetings. I thank them in return, as do, of course, the Romanian Presidency and the Commissioner. But I do not want to have a false impression with this consensus that emerges today on this text, with the impression that this negotiation went smoothly because, as has been said, the timetable was very tight, which was a first challenge. I think we can be proud of having succeeded in completing this negotiation and reaching this agreement on a very good text before the end of this mandate. It's a really great thing and it hasn't been easy. On principle, everyone is in for the protection of whistleblowers, that's fine and it's happy. But I still wanted to point out that we have had to deal with some adversity, particularly on the part of some States in the Council. It is indeed important to point out, for the sake of transparency and not to hide anything from our fellow citizens, that everything has not been so simple and that unfortunately some Member States, not least France allied with Hungary and Austria, have tried to diminish the scope of the protection offered by this text. And if we have finally reached this ambitious agreement, it is thanks to the mobilization of all. As I said, the mobilization of NGOs, which I would like to salute once again for their daily work alongside whistleblowers and for their commitment to this text, has been extremely valuable to us. May they be sincerely thanked here. I also wanted to renew my thanks to the Romanian Presidency, to the Commission for their real work in order to reach a broad consensus and for the colleagues who have also mobilised to put pressure on their government so that we can reach this agreement. It is, I think, a good illustration of the role of the European Parliament, its role as a representative of the general interest of Europeans and its ability to influence the course of events and the legislative process. I think it is important that all our citizens have that in mind as we approach the election deadlines.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission has made it very clear to this Parliament and beyond, that it is following very closely, and with great concern, developments concerning the rule of law in Romania. We have repeatedly said that Romania needs to put the reform process back on track and to do so urgently. This means going forwards, not backwards, and abstaining from any steps which would reverse the progress accomplished over the past years.  The Commission, and in particular the First Vice-President, Frans Timmermans, has personally engaged with Prime Minister Dăncilă, and the respective experts have met on several occasions for constructive discussions and dialogue.  The Commission always made it clear that talking for the sake of talking will not be enough and concrete actions from the Romanian side will be needed sooner rather than later. The College discussed the situation two weeks ago. Regrettably, we have not yet been able to conclude that Romania is back on the right track. If our concerns are not met, the Commission will have to act, and to use the means at its disposal.  Today’s discussion is not about technical issues or to update you that against the backdrop of already clear backtracking identified in November, progress on the CVM (cooperation and verification mechanism) recommendations has been stalled, or to discuss that the latest Romanian legislative developments transposing a number of EU directives could raise concerns about potential incompatibility with EU law, or to mention further eroding confidence through recent executive ordinances and controversial appointment procedures. The situation around the nomination procedure for the next European Public Prosecutor’s Office chief has also not contributed.  Today’s discussion is about very real risks of further steps backwards in Romania regarding the rule of law and, more specifically, as regards the independence of the judiciary and the fight against corruption.  First, the possible amendments of the criminal code and the criminal procedure code: such fundamental issues need careful preparation, widespread consultation of the magistracy and stakeholders, and a very clear understanding of the consequences of change. Any the action taken should be compatible with EU law and international obligations, as well as CVM recommendations such as the fight against corruption. The Romanian authorities would be taking a risk in moving ahead without such a process and this might lead to creating a systemic, de facto impunity for high office holders who were sentenced for corruption.  Second, regarding the High Court of Cassation and Justice and a possible follow-up to a constitutional court judgment that has required changes to the composition of panels of five judges: there are serious questions about what is needed for the follow-up and these cannot be separated from the potential consequences of re-opening past cases, something which in itself could amount to a massive interference in the independence of the judiciary. The risk of massive disruption to the Romanian criminal justice system, including many corruption cases, cannot be ignored.  Third, the issue of appointments of prosecutors and, in particular, the need for a robust and independent system of appointing top prosecutors: this is not a new issue but the checks and balances have been successively watered down. The result is highly controversial procedures to appoint top prosecutors, the Prosecutor General and the chief anti-corruption prosecutor.  Fourth, the Special Prosecution Section set up to investigate magistrates: concerns about the structure had previously been raised in the CVM report by the Venice Commission and by the anti-corruption body GRECO. Yet, the government is reinforcing this structure. All these elements, all of them, raise major concerns taken separately. Together, they start to amount to a very worrying pattern. Recent months have been characterised by a very volatile situation in Romania, with a series of rushed decisions being taken on essential matters. If these concerns are not met, the Commission will have to act and to use all the means at its disposal.  The Commission therefore urges Romania to take time to consult, getting as close as possible to a consensus and drawing on advice from the Venice Commission as well as from the CVM process. It is not too late for Romania to revert to the path of reform.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Unfortunately, the Presidency of the Council cannot be welcomed, although there are many good reasons why this Presidency of the Council should be listening to this. Commissioner, we have to deal with the fact that Romania is leading the European Union, and I am already concerned – stunned and deeply affected, because we have never seen the collapse of the rule of law in such a rapid succession. No other state in the European Union has dared to do what Romania dares to do. I hope that the Romanians want to be a singular story. It would be good if the S&D were to move away early and much more decisively from this issue, which is happening in Romania. I can only advise the Commission on this: we are advising on the Article 7 procedure. We also advise stopping money because we can no longer protect the money in the face of the collapse of the rule of law. It is the responsibility of an obviously overwhelmed government, which is allowed to give up an obviously overwhelmed Presidency. The Romanian Government is the perpetrator and it creates victims, and the first victim is the independent judiciary. It thus promotes a considerable amount of corruption. We see a Socialist parliamentary leader and party leader – convicted at first instance of fraud – who bears a great deal of responsibility for this. This story needs to be addressed, including by the S&D, because I think that double standards would be quite bad here. We see a Constitutional Court dealing with its case and facing considerable pressure. We see a postponement of the appeal process. We see the former Attorney General Kövesi being overrun with ever new trials and flimsy accusations and subjected to enormous pressure – again an act of revenge. She is the candidate of the two committees responsible for the new European Public Prosecutor's Office, and she is the candidate of the selection committee. Unfortunately, unfortunately, the Council has done little – nothing at all – to sanction these machinations of the Presidency. The Council therefore has a clear share of responsibility. It is prepared to reward Romania for these attacks on the rule of law. And that is something that must be absolutely rejected. The French candidate cannot therefore become the first European Public Prosecutor. His candidacy is the fig leaf behind which are unprecedented violations of the law and against the Romanian candidate of Parliament. It has long been about more than a post for the European Public Prosecutor. It is about the credibility of Europe and also about the credibility of the Commission and the first Vice-President. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting this intervention. I shall ask the following question in Romanian, so you can use the interpretation system.  – Mrs Gräßle, you said in your intervention reprehensible things about the Constitutional Court in Romania. I would like to ask you - and I am challenging you - how can you explain to my Romanians that members of the Constitutional Court can be party members in your country?

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Dear Mr President, thank you for the question. I have not even complained that the Constitutional Court does have politicians as members. The question is whether these politicians are complying with the law.  Incidentally, I have defended the Constitutional Court because it is being put under such pressure at the moment – by individual politicians. That is what it is all about. I would also like to say to you that it is high time that the Socialist Group took a position on this.  And why are all Romanians always allowed to vote when it comes to Romanian issues? This is a matter for the whole of Europe. We have seen it in the candidate for the Court of Auditors, who, incidentally, has at least not told us the truth about the companies it has and which receive European money. We have seen it with the candidate for the Prosecutor General's Office.  When will the S&D Group finally get its way to consider Romanian issues as European issues? It is not a matter for the Romanians.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to say that the President is chairing the sitting here, not Mr Preda. Unlike the previous speaker, I believe that the Romanian Presidency has achieved a great deal in the time available, despite all the fears and inconveniences. It is all the more surprising that ... (Interjede by Mr Preda) (Reply from Mr Weidenholzer: You can also listen to me, Mr Preda. A bit of discipline would be required.) ... that we must have this urgent debate today. This is not the first time that we have discussed these issues. In November, this House made it clear in a resolution that the revision of the judiciary and criminal law rules in Romania must not affect the independence of the judiciary, because that is the only way to combat corruption in a sustainable way. Control and counter-control must be established and parliamentary surveillance of the intelligence services strengthened. Unfortunately, our demands have not received the necessary attention. That is very regrettable. It is not against Romania; it is about our common understanding of the law. A functioning rule of law is the essential pillar of the common Europe, and this has been clearly defined in the Copenhagen criteria. Insisting on compliance with them is therefore not interference in the internal affairs of a Member State, it is in all our interests. Of course, this must not be one-sided and super-teacher-like. But we must consolidate the common principles of the rule of law in dialogue. That is our message towards Bucharest. Only in this way will East and West grow together.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: on behalf of the ECR group. – Madam President, today in Romania a group of corrupt politicians led by the convicted and socialist Dragnea, who is definitively convicted and has new trials, has taken the country in his hand and is throwing it to the ground. It doesn't follow the government program announced at the election, it changes laws, it erases crimes, it politically subordinates judges and prosecutors, it turns investment money into electoral bribes, it destroys the heart of democracy so that they, corrupt politicians, get rid of justice. The fate of 20 million people lies, after all, in the scale of the fate of one, with the salvation of one? Romanians are not an inert people, we have been out on the streets for over two years. We're gassed, we're beaten, we're shot with rubber bullets or we're hit with hand grenades. That doesn't stop us from getting out. Further on, our path is Europe. We are desperately witnessing the sinking of the country hit by Dragnea, Tariceanu and their gang. I can't shut up. You can't let us end up as prisoners of a few hundred politicians who have the levers of power in their hands. I ask you to help Romania because, under the appearance of democracy, Romania is living today a criminal dictatorship and the tragedy of emptying the country. Four million Romanians have left the country in recent years alone. Our break from Europe is the nightmare that our history has lived for decades. This is the last train we can catch. We want to go to Europe!

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner. I have to start by saying that I share Ms Gräßle’s irritation about the absence of the Council, not least because it is the country concerned. (Applause) But hold your applause until I have finished, because you may not be so happy any more – I also regret the absence of Mr Timmermans. No offence, Madam Commissioner, but he is the Commissioner and the Vice—President in charge. And what has he done over the last five years? Just last week, the Commission presented a kind of communication on the rule of law which was hardly worth the paper it was written on, and Mr Timmermans didn’t even bother to show up at the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) to present it. No, he left it to his civil servants. Where is he today? What has he done in the last five years? Because now I’m coming to the partisan issue. I am a bit tired of having debates here – today it’s about Romania and it’s the EPP criticising, tomorrow it will be about Hungary and the Socialists will be criticising and the EPP will be, well, not silent because I know that some of you are indeed critical, I know that Ms Gräßle is very outspoken and very, very honest, and some other EPP Members as well – but these debates are always turned into a partisan issue. It is not a partisan issue. This is about the values laid down in Article 2 of the Treaties that concern us all, regardless of party political colour. I don’t understand – two-and-a-half years ago this House adopted a position, a proposal for a DRF pact, which is a general mechanism covering all the Member States, all the Governments and the Commission. And again, I’m not pointing at you Madam Commissioner, but Mr Timmermans is responsible here. Mr Timmermans said ‘oh, we don’t need that because we’ve got all the tools in the toolbox that we need’. Well, we don’t. Mr Timmermans is a Spitzenkandidat, but Mr Weber is also a Spitzenkandidat. So I would like to know from both Spitzenkandidaten, who are conspicuously absent, both as group leader and Vice—President of the Commission, what they intend to do once they are President of the Commission. Will President of the Commission Weber do what he voted for as MEP Weber, namely propose a fully—fledged DRF mechanism applying equally to all the Member States? To be perfectly clear here, my group, the ALDE Group, has firmly distanced itself from the ALDE Romania party in government because we are disappointed, not just about the changes to the penal code, but also about their failure to support equal marriage or indeed civil partnership. We are very disappointed about the attitude of the Romanian Government in the case of Ms Kövesi, and we are also very disappointed about their attempts to try and prevent the registration of new parties who want to run in the European elections. So I think we should insist on a DRF pact in the next period. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: "blue card" question. I agree with your criticism of the Commission, by Mr Timmermans himself, but - without wishing to be partisan - the Chairman of your group, Mr Verhofstadt, has so far said nothing about the situation in Romania. He was silent. The drift did not begin three months ago, ma'am, and when you were asked to do something, you did not move. You too, madam, are doing an electoral calculation. Tell me: why did Mr Verhofstadt not say anything? Do his personal friendships with Mr. Tericeanu or his private friendships matter more than the principles you invoke?

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card answer. – You’ve got it completely wrong. Just read the minutes of this House – the attitude of this Group has been completely solid. If the EPP had been equally solid on Mr Orban, we wouldn’t be in the situation that we are in with Hungary. We have to be very critical of what happens in Romania. We have, as I said, formally taken our distance from the other party that is in government, and asked the European ALDE party to expel them from our political family. We are very firm. We do this with a heavy heart because, indeed, there are many years of political friendship. But we stand by our principles, contrary to the EPP which has still not taken its distance from Mr Orban. I recommend that you read the minutes of this House because I personally, Mr Preda, took part in the debate on Romania and I’ve been very critical, very critical, Mr Preda, and I would beg you to be equally critical of your Member, Mr Orban. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Madam in 't Veld, I have two short questions to your address. Do you know how many times the Constitutional Court of Romania has declared Mrs Kövesi's actions as unconstitutional? How many times has Mrs Kövesi been declared to have violated the Constitution in Romania? And two, do you know that in the case - which is also on your radar, the open case for abuse against Mrs Kövesi - the most important testimonies are those of Mrs Kövesi's former deputies, two prosecutors from the National Anti-Corruption Directorate who testified against Mrs Kövesi? Then how can you say that there is political pressure in this case?

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card answer. – I’m not going to enter into the details of the court case but to my knowledge, recently the court has judged … (Objections from Mr Cristea) … can I finish, do you want to hear, are you interested in the reply? I’ve got 30 seconds and half of it has already gone. What I do know first of all is that the court has already allowed Ms Kövesi to travel and to speak.  The point is that the arguments I always hear against do not make the matter any better, because the image that we have here is of a complete mess, and what we need is the rule of law, not just for the European Union, but for the people in Romania, because young people are craving a country that is stable, where the government is reliable and clean, and all the stories saying, oh, you know, somebody’s in court, and then there’s the secret services interfering. Do you really think that makes it better? I don’t think so.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the rule of law is not left wing or right wing, and it’s very painful to see here that the Romanian Government is backing up the Hungarian Government by not putting the report on Hungary on the agenda. Everybody has said it, but it’s incredibly disappointing. The Romanian Presidency is not here, that is unbelievable. It’s also the Presidency that is de-legitimising the Parliament’s candidate for the European Public Prosecutor, and with that actually de-legitimising the whole process. Fighting corruption is crucial in the rule of law, and we’ve got a country that is seriously backsliding and that is chairing the European Council right now. Give me another example... oh, I know, January 2011 when the Hungarian Government was chair of the Council. That was also half a year when nothing happened. People, we need to be ashamed of this: six weeks before the European elections and we’ve got this as an example.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, the EU is more than just a single market or an economic partnership. It is a union of countries that have come together in the aftermath of war and misery, and have decided that they stand together stronger than alone. Unity makes power. That's right. But that is only true when that unity is built on a solid foundation of shared values. And there's a big challenge there right now. We are seeing some Member States moving away from the values on which the EU is built. At the same time, we see the lack of a consistent, unambiguous response from the European Commission. First Vice-President Timmermans did not need an incentive in the case of Poland. He started an Article 7 procedure immediately, effectively, rightly and without a doubt. Unfortunately, however, there is little sign of this kind of decisiveness towards a country such as Romania or, for example, Malta. "Pop and wet" seems to be the motto towards Bucharest and Valletta. We cannot afford to measure with double standards in the European Union. Values cannot be defended only if it is politically convenient. They're way too important for that. Also – or indeed right – if your friends don't take it so closely with the rule of law, you have to hold up a mirror to them. I sincerely hope, therefore, that in the case of Romania, but certainly in the case of Malta, the European Commission will finally do so.

name: Dan NICA
text: – Madam President, unfortunately today we have again an electoral debate, a debate in which, without any clarification or any concrete information being said about Romania, we have to say what the truth is and, above all, to combat many of the things that have been said and are false. What is the state of the rule of law? Ladies and gentlemen - the rule of law without there being rights and freedoms for citizens does not exist.  In 2009, Romania's attorney general signed a secret protocol with the intelligence services. Surprisingly - the attorney general was Kövesi. For two years, revelations began to emerge about a long series of secret protocols concluded with the intelligence services, and Romanians were able to find out with horror, with fear, with fear that these secret protocols existed and that these secret protocols led to abominable abuses and injustices. I think it's fair to say that Romanians hate the double standard. I hate the double standard in court. I hate the double standard in everything that means the things that are their daily life: food that is counterfeit and come and have invaded the Romanian market, endangering their health, pharmaceuticals. Romanians are not admitted to the Schengen area although all conditions have been met since 2011. There are millions of Romanians in all airports. At all border crossingpoints European citizens are on one side and Romanians on the other. 80% of Romanians in all opinion polls say that it is inadmissible and do not recognise as legitimate the abuses that have been made in court, these abuses that must be ended once and for all. And I want you to know why i'm saying these things, because they've been able to see testimonies, testimonies, and testimonies on television every day. And Romanians are sensitive because they experienced these abuses during the communist period and do not want to accept that there are judges who are blackmailed, judges and prosecutors who are filmed in the bathroom, in the bedroom so that they can be blackmailed to be indicated and asked for a certain solution in a file.  Romanians want to be treated as equal partners, as citizens of the European Union. Romanians do not want or accept this discrimination, which is based on absolutely nothing concrete and is undeserved. To all those who have ears to hear and eyes to see we say one thing: Romania deserves better and Romanians deserve better!

name: Renate WEBER
text: – Madam President, Romania is in a mechanism of cooperation and verification with the European Commission. Not once have Romanian politicians been severely criticised in CVM reports for public statements on concrete cases in the courts, considering such practices to be an interference in the courts. And yet, a few weeks ago, the leaders of this European Parliament urged the Romanian authorities, public prosecutors and courts alike to stop an investigation against a Romanian citizen who had been respected by all the procedural rights provided for by law. The Superior Council of Magistracy of Romania, the constitutional guarantor of the independence of the judiciary, said that these leaders, Antonio Tajani, Manfred Weber, Guy Verhofstadt, through their statements put pressure on the national judge who was to settle the case, an interference with the consequence of undermining the independence of the judiciary. It is time, fellow Europeans, to stop with double standards and behave exactly as you ask politicians in other countries, even in the election campaign.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Madam President, I must say that I too regret that the Romanian Government is not represented today by anyone, neither to participate in the debate about Romania nor to represent the rotating presidency of the European Council. This is all that is contemptuous of the institutions and of our Parliament and of the Council. It is regrettable that at the first Romanian presidency we are in this situation. I would like to say, on the other hand, that there had to be someone here because, unfortunately, the Bucharest regime, the Romanian regime, is no longer a rule of law. It is no longer a rule of law because the ruling majority since 2016 does exactly what Mr Nica described, namely enormous pressure on judges, prosecutors, on the entire body of magistrates, even creating institutions to force them to reverse decisions taken, final decisions, to force them not to pursue acts of corruption. Everything, after all, to save the Marafoi. They have at the head of the party a man convicted of corruption twice, a man who is at the head of the House. Tell me a country in the European Union since the Second World War, which has had as its leader a party - the most important in number and which has continued to remain in this position - someone convicted twice. Who is awarded in the European Union for stealing? How can we accept this coalition of scoundrels who want to destroy a country for a March? That's the question.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, let me make a remark: this debate is a failure, Commissioner, is apparent from the presence. There are twenty people here - the leaders, the most critical of Romania, are missing from here, they are cowards. Recently, Mr Weber dared to come to Romania, to my country, to tell the government to stop an ongoing process.  Commissioner, you are a specialist, you know well that in terms of judicial organisation and in the area of justice, neither the government of that country nor European officials can interfere. And I want to tell you that through the interventions of European officials you have actually affected justice in Romania. The citizens of Romania do not understand why certain officials, certain MEPs are meddling in ongoing processes.  What do we want? Do we want a common Europe? How can we make a common Europe? Is it a campaign? Yes, because Mr. Preda earlier said "do your campaign." That means the EPP, which triggered this analysis, is campaigning.  Commissioner, you do not have to answer me, but the Romanians. Understand what you've presented here - because it's registering. You haven't given even one example of a violation of the rule of law - one! The Romanian government on the rotating presidency is successful! Are you sorry he's successful, that he's done so many files? What are you doing this for? It ended last year with a resolution, an unfair resolution, and you know, Commissioner, that there is a point there that you would not put in any other country. Blame Romania for changing a head of institution. Well, that head of institution has wreaked havoc on the justice system. Not to mention the protocols he admitted - I'm talking about people's lives, lost trials, thousands of lawsuits. You even said that some lawsuits need to be resumed. Leave people with injustice or resume trials? Who are you defending? Romania is not Kövesi! Romania is not a person! Romania means twenty million people - and please treat them with respect.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Madam President, undermining the independence of the judiciary; undermining the independence of the prosecutors; hindering new parties from being established; trying to legalise corruption; fighting not corruption but those who fight corruption; getting rid of uncomfortable leaders of independent authorities; prohibiting them from leaving the country. Of course this is a collapse of the rule of law. And what worries me maybe most is the denials. But I must say also, Mr Weidenholzer, the silence from the Socialist Group is thundering. Your contribution here tonight was not impressive, and I will tell you why. The defence of rule of law and democracy does not follow party colours. The  misuse of power in Hungary or in Poland doesn’t excuse it in Romania, and I have heard you – all of you – be very vocal, just as I am about Hungary, just as I am about Poland. But your silence is thundering. You’re misusing your obligation to defend democracy: you as a leader here tonight in the Socialist Group. That is wrong.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: – Madam President, well where on earth is Vice-President Timmermans? I don’t – do I see him? No. Where is the Romanian Presidency? I don’t see them either. The European Union was founded in order to prosper peace, democratic principles and the rule of law. As my EPP colleagues, I am extremely concerned about the state of the rule of law and the recent developments in Romania. We cannot accept the Romanian Government’s continuous attempts to make changes to the Romanian penal code through emergency ordinance, which aim at decriminalising corruption progressively. We cannot accept the continuous attempts to interfere with the independence of the judiciary. The special section for investigations, which puts pressure on the judges and prosecutors, has to be stopped. All in all, defending the rule of law and urging the Romanian Government to stop acting against the core values of the European Union should be considered as top priorities for all of us. And by the way, I would advise Madam in 't Veld to take a closer look at the decision the EPP made in Brussels on 20 March. I don’t think your comments do full justice to that decision.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Madam President, I would like to remind colleagues at the EPP - they may not have found out, perhaps they were absent - that the decision not to represent the Council at this debate belongs to the Conference of Presidents. Gentlemen colleagues, ask your group leader, ask yourself how your proposal disappeared before... (The President withdrew the speaker's word)

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: You should have invoked an article, it is not a point of order.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, Madam Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Romania is a pro-European country. The Romanian people want European values, they want justice, they want justice, they want the rule of law. For two years, hundreds of thousands of people have been take to the streets to defend European values. Politicians have a duty to always listen to the will of the people, and politicians are never allowed to change laws in their own interest. I say very clearly: millions of honest people in Romania want neither amnesty nor pardon. And therefore, I call on the Romanian Government to take into account and implement all the recommendations of independent experts from the Venice Commission, the recommendations expressed by the European Commission in the case of the cooperation and verification mechanism. The Romanian government has a duty to listen to the people, and that is why the President of Romania, Mr Klaus Johannis, has called for 26 May a referendum in which the Romanian people can express themselves on what kind of justice they want. People can say very clearly that they do not want amnesty and pardon and do not want to amend the criminal law overnight in an untimely way. Criminal legislation must be amended in the light of the opinion of the magistrates, the opinion of NGOs and, of course, taking into account the recommendations of our international partners. Please, Commissioner, I ask the European Commission to stand with the Romanian people in this fight for justice and for European values. [The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).]

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. Mr. Mureşan, you said that laws have been changed... I'm actually going into a question. Because you have made a statement - that laws in the field of justice have been amended overnight - can you give the example of a single law, apart from the one amended by Mr Cioloş overnight with Minister Prune? Do you know of any other laws that changed overnight?

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: Answer to a question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Thank you to Mrs Grapini for the question. It is a long string of emergency ordinances given by the last three governments of Romania, the first at the end of January 2017, Emergency Ordinance No. 13, which brought hundreds of thousands of people to Romania, an ordinance designed to weaken the fight against corruption, to weaken the rule of law in Romania.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the Romanians and I know what it is to be in your shoes, being Hungarian. But this speech is against double standards and I have to say that Ms Gräßle has reconsidered many of the accusations that I’m against Hungary, as also this time against Romania. Many times it comes to light – how come Romania has come so far when it comes to the integration of the poorest people? Today there is a crisis situation all around Europe, with people being sent out of their settlements because EU money is only very slowly coming to these places in Europe. So I would like to ask the Romanian Presidency to stand together with the Council, with the Commission – several Commissioners, among them Madam Crețu – to make sure that the unused money in the Structural Funds will be very quickly used to help those citizens of Europe who are not receiving the EU money being spent on them because there are difficulties in the bureaucracy and therefore they will be evicted. So please, let’s stop eviction everywhere in the Roma settlements around Europe... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, your silence in the face of abuses in Romania is deafening. I want to make it very clear to you: my party's objective is to strengthen the European project and eliminate the double standards that you tolerate. The populism and extremism that threaten the European project are rooted in the departure of European officials from what is happening in European capitals. Due to the lack of common sense in the European Commission's approaches to the CVM and the proven abuses in my country, the reputation of the European Union suffers. The involvement of Brussels, its calls for involvement in judicial and constitutional processes in Romania is unacceptable. Some of you will also find yourself in the Commission's forthcoming formula and ask you to stop the brutal interference in the judicial and constitutional processes of the Member States. You are ready to use us as teaching material just to win a few percent in your internal electoral battles. (The President withdrew the speaker's word)

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner Jourová said that if the situation in Romania does not change, the Commission will take the necessary action. Fortunately, this Commission will not take any action, it has already taken enough harmful measures during this term of office. At most, he can make electoral gestures, and Mr Timmermans, who has been asked, will probably still make many such political gestures, using his position. As far as Romania is concerned, however, the situation in Romania is difficult and no less complicated than in the United Kingdom. I do not like the tolerance of power for so-called petty corruption, because corruption is always evil, and widespread corruption is a common evil, but I also do not like the permanent, long-standing surveillance of politicians, because the surveillance society will never be free. Also free will not be a nation whose principle becomes to turn to the foreign as the arbiter of its own problems. This problem must be solved in the interest of Europe by the Romanians themselves.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: – Madam President, to provoke a debate about the rule of law, a fundamental institution in the European Union, and not to come to it means that either you are talking about the debate and the rule of law and using it only for formal and political reasons, or that you realize that it is a debate that dishonors. I don't know if it dishonors us in this hemicicle, but anyway it's a debate that has no substance whatsoever. It's kind of like a rerun of Steven Spielberg's film, Commissioner, when someone was convicted of what they were thinking. That's what you did today, because if you had the modicum of decency to check what happened in Romania, you would have seen that we didn't pass any laws and that's why we're being criticised. But I understand the need for votes, I understand the desire of some to stay in power, to perpetuate their power, but you must also understand that this kind of behaviour is driving the citizen away from Europe and, for that, I think it is worth abandoning the smattering of votes and populism that you have shown today.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. I have a specific question for Commissioner Jurová. Are Mrs Jurová aware of the criminal case of István Beke and Zoltán Szőcs of Târgu-Mureş? This is a good example – I say in quotation marks that it is good – of what has been repeatedly said here, that politics exerts a pressing effect on the criminal justice system and, in the most desidating Bolshevik way, intertwined with the secret services, using politics, justice, criminal justice, imprisonment and pre-trial detention to achieve political objectives. In the case of Beke and Zoltán Szőcs, in a concept criminal trial, those who fight exclusively for the human rights of the Hungarian national community were given five years imprisonment, so Romania considers them political opponents and imprisons them. What do you know about this case and what are your advice to the next of kin?

name: Răzvan POPA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, unfortunately, I note that again it is not a debate, but it is a festival of electoral slogans of those who initiated this so-called debate, because there is no concrete element and you said at the beginning of the discussion that you do not want to discuss concrete things. In fact, no one wants to talk about concrete things, just about concerns and risks. Well, Commissioner, we should worry, if you will, and discuss risks when senior European officials here at this rostrum have told the Romanian magistrates what and how to do, which is unacceptable. The rule of law means letting justice do its job, not dictating it, regardless of the rank they have, or have, what and how to do.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I begin my intervention by asking a question: when we talk about the rule of law, are we talking about whether or not we are talking about respect for citizens' rights and freedoms? Because that is what this is about, this is the struggle and effort that the Romanian government is making, to ensure a fair justice system, in which citizens' rights and freedoms are respected, in which we fight against secret protocols, we fight against the abuses of prosecutors, we fight to stop having lives and careers destroyed. That is why I would like to convey to all the political forces in this Parliament who use Romania as an election campaign theme, that the votes are won by turning to the vote, by the credibility that you have in the eyes of the electorate. I think it is unacceptable that a debate should be again being conducted on the eve of the election campaign attacking the internal politics of a Member State. We are talking again about a double measure at the level of the European institutions and this is unacceptable. I believe that what is happening here today is just an electoral political game, which once again affects the credibility of the European Parliament... (The President withdrew the speaker's word)

name: Mircea DIACONU
text: – Madam President, it is difficult for me to understand how we can talk about something, which is called the rule of law, which is not defined. As long as criminal policy is national competence - and the differences between the criminal policies of the Member States are huge - it is impossible to make any assessment. That's why, unfortunately, I have to say, here's just noise. So all that's going on is just noise, both and nothing more. It's Romanian, national competence. I too expect, personally, from the Romanian justice system and from the Romanian Parliament to set its rules, of course, according to European principles. Otherwise, unfortunately, that's what I have to say, in Romania really is not the rule of law, in my opinion, it didn't get to be. So there's a lot of work to be done until we're there. However, I expect the next Parliament to define the rule of law in form and in fact.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, Romania is my country and, as long as I am here and represent it in the European Parliament, I will not allow anyone to tell lies about it. Romania is the rule of law. I say it again - Romania is the rule of law. However, the image that some Romanian parties are trying to project in the public space is totally different. The electoral interests of the opposition and the political interests of some European parties make the image of justice in Romania misrepresented. Those who claim in Europe Romania's failure to comply with the rule of law are the same ones who at home in the country are pressuring the judiciary, trying to influence the legal system for the conviction, even without evidence, of some politicians or, on the contrary, they are pressuring the justice of leniency against certain persons in their circle of influence. When members of the Romanian opposition notice certain issues that seem to them to be non-compliant with the law, they should, first of all, stop violating it by the pressures they are putting on justice. (The President withdrew the speaker's word)

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, I voted here in this Parliament for Romania to join the EU and fought those who wanted to keep Romania out, and then the ransom because of the Moratorium on the International Adoption of Children. I backed all those in Romania who fought the immoral and corrupt business of exporting Romanian children, most were from the PSD. Fifteen years later I am appalled that the EU is under a Romanian Presidency which does not even bother to be here today, which is captured by a PSD leader, Liviu Dragnea, whom the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) identifies as having created a criminal organisation to steal millions in EU funds. As a socialist, I have higher demands from my own political family and that is why I have not been shy in criticising what’s going on in Romania, and I am relieved to see that, finally, my Group has had the courage to suspend the Romanian PSD while this criminal capture persists. As Commissioner Jourová said, this is about the rule of law, not only in Romania but in the EU. And if you want to back all these Romanian citizens who braved the harsh winter demanding, indeed, the rule of law, then we have to back them in the fight against corruption.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Jourová, I am intervening from socialist banking in this debate on the rule of law in Romania. And I do not do so in Romanian, Hungarian or Polish, respected official languages of the Union which have been very present in this debate, for a transparent reason. The debate on the fight against corruption, the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights is often subverted in a debate of cross-accusations between those countries that have been subject to Article 7 for breach of the principles enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union and another country in which there has been no set of constitutional reforms directly aggressive against those principles. But the fundamental thing is that the work is yet to be done. A reliable, robust, verification mechanism for complying with the principles enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. Rule of law, fundamental rights, democratic quality and also the fight against corruption. And that mechanism, Mrs Jourová, is enforceable on the Commission, in accordance with the resolutions we have adopted in this European Parliament. We demand that the Commission come from the next endowment of the European Parliament, following the elections of 26 May.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first let me express the conviction that I represent here the whole College, the whole Commission. So that’s the reaction for you who criticised First Vice-President Timmermans for not being here today. Frans Timmermans has engaged very intensively in continuous, long-lasting dialogue with the Romanian authorities and he is the last person who should be criticised for doing something wrong or something negative against Romania.  The second comment: the Commission does not interfere in individual cases in Romania. This is the reaction to Ms Grapini. This is our principle: we do not interfere. We are looking at a systemic situation, at the situation in the legislation, and that’s why we are addressing the recent legislative changes which we see in Romania, because the cumulative potential of the individual changes might lead to the breach of the rule of law in Romania. Last comment to Ms Morvai: No, I don’t know the basis.  I very well remember my own case from 2006. I was accused of corruption in 2006, with a very dirty political case. It was purely motivated by political interests and it was a charade for the media, and I still remember that when sitting in the jail, not for a single second did I believe that any judge in my country would send me to jail after indictment in the court. I believed in independent justice in my country and by the way the case never got to the court because there was not the slightest evidence. It was just politically initiated, a dirty game for the media.  I remember it very well and it’s a paradox that Romania was the country which offered me work after this, because everything was destroyed by this. I will not go into details but it also affected horribly my family. I worked in Romania. This country gave me a chance to provide my knowledge and expertise and that’s why I should be the last person who could be accused now of doing something against Romania.  I just have to share the view that in Romania we might get into the situation of irreversible changes in the judiciary system, the systemic breach of rule of law, where the independence and impartiality of the judiciary is endangered. I was following closely what Romania is doing through the CVM exercise. I was happy about the reform going in the right direction and at the same time, I was very scared about the changes which started to go in a very wrong direction and this is where we are now.  The independent judiciary is a very important pillar of the democratic state and it is something which is being developed over decades. In all the Member States we saw a very long process which led to the well-balanced constitutional system, with a very strong independent judiciary as the main part of it, or one of the main parts. But it can be destroyed literally overnight and this is what the Commission doesn’t want to happen in Romania.  So again, the debate, the dialogue is ongoing. I agree with those of you who said that Romania and the Romanians deserve more. So we would like to help Romania. Now the debate is ongoing on a technical level, I would wish us to come back to the political level and have a positive dialogue which will lead to positive changes and the reform coming back on track in Romania.  (Applause)

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, investment funds provide opportunities for European citizens to save for their future. They are also an important tool to channel private savings into the economy and increase funding for European companies. But today the markets for investment funds are mostly national. For example, 70% of investment funds are sold only in the domestic market. The share of UCITS funds – that is marketed in more than three countries – is relatively low, 37%, and for alternative investment funds the share is even lower, only around 3%. This is partly due to regulatory barriers that hinder cross—border fund distribution. As part of the capital markets union, the Commission proposed measures to reduce these barriers and improve the functioning of the single market for European investment funds. Our goal is simple. We want managers from anywhere in the EU to be able to easily sell their funds across the EU without compromising on investor protection. We propose to achieve this by reducing administrative burdens and by improving clarity for fund managers who want to market their funds across the EU. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Wolf Klinz, and the shadow rapporteurs for making efforts to advance the file quickly. (Interruption due to an interpretation problem)  I would also like to congratulate you for having quickly achieved a political agreement with the Council in trilogue negotiations. The Commission supports the agreement reached. It strikes the right balance between facilitating cross—border distribution of investment funds and ensuring investor protection. I would give you one example of this careful balance. Parliament and the Member States decided to allow managers to promote actively the existing funds to potential new investors without having to comply with all the marketing rules. At the same time, the co-legislators introduced safeguards to ensure sound supervision of these practices and limit the risk of the circumvention of EU rules. I hope that tomorrow’s vote will confirm this important building block of the capital markets union.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the negotiating team under the authority of our rapporteur Wolf Klinz, who is expected to arrive any minute, for the result that has been achieved on this important issue. Tomorrow we will vote on an important text for the completion of the Capital Markets Union, as Vice-President Dombrovskis has just pointed out. The outgoing Commission, whose work I welcome in this area, had wished to provide precise and targeted responses to the remaining barriers to cross-border investment within the Union. The agreement reached with the Council during the inter-institutional negotiations appears satisfactory and balanced. It takes into account most of the issues that had been raised by Parliament. In particular, it proposes to make the procedure for denoting funds more pragmatic, abolishing the logic of thresholds which was inherently arbitrary. Similarly, with regard to pre-marketing, under the impetus of Parliament, the mechanism has been extended to pre-existing funds and the requirements for pre-marketing documents have been streamlined. This will make the tool more efficient and responsive to its objectives. In total, we have managed to maintain the necessary safeguards to prevent these new opportunities from giving rise to possible circumventions, especially from actors from third countries. Finally, while the idea of European supervision, at the level of a European authority, sometimes seems to be disputed, I am pleased to see that the compromise that meets Parliament's will gives an increased role to the European Financial Markets Authority, ESMA. This move towards more common supervision is an essential part of the smooth and efficient functioning of our capital markets union.

name: Mady DELVAUX
text: On behalf of the Group of President and President, I would like to thank the team and especially our rapporteur, Mr Klinz, who has conducted our debates and trilogues very effectively, which allows us to close the file before the end of the mandate. The aim of this regulation is to facilitate the cross-border distribution of investment funds, as most European funds are currently offered in only one Member State, their national state, and many managers are reluctant to enter a new market, which reduces the choice of investors in that country. However, we need investors and capital in Europe to finance our economy, hence this proposal which should remove barriers and encourage funds to explore the potential of a new market, for example by defining what marketing pricing is. It also harmonizes the conditions under which funds can leave a Member State's market if the expected success is not achieved. We have been very insistent that the supervisory authorities be informed of the activities of the funds in a given state so that they can carry out their monitoring mission and that there is a genuine exchange of information between the supervisory authorities, but also with the European Authority. Indeed, these are the necessary conditions to ensure adequate information and protection of investors, this was our main concern. Thanks to the trade-offs, we are also confident that fund managers will continue to fulfill their obligation to inform investors in a country, even after leaving it. I would not like to end without saying a word about the PRIIP and the key information document. My group did not request that the UCITS be given an additional two years before they were obliged to apply the provisions relating to the key information document. I call on the Commission to speed up the work so that this extension is not two years but as short as possible.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, the development of the European capital market is indeed a necessity, especially at a time when the banking system itself cannot respond to the liquidity necessary for the development of the real economy. For this reason, collective investment funds can play an important role and even raise many billions of euros. At the same time, however, we must note that to a large extent these funds are not directed to the real economy. In practice, they are part and function of what we call the 'casino economy', which is why there must be additional control. Facilitation at cross-border level, but at the same time national supervisory authorities must keep an eye open and be able to monitor developments and see that these funds are indeed invested in the real economy and investors themselves are protected.

name: Stefan GEHROLD
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The rules to be adopted to facilitate the cross-border distribution of investment funds are an important step towards removing obstacles in the internal market. They promote communication and transparency and lead to a more integrated market.  The increase in competition allows financial service providers to offer an expanded range of products. This creates more opportunities for investors, which in turn has a positive impact on financing conditions, both for individuals and for businesses, especially SMEs.  I say this here not only as an economic and financial politician, but also as a development politician. Our commitment should go beyond the borders of Europe and also promote prosperity among our partners. I therefore consider it a duty to provide and support businesses and their cross-border cooperation, and I welcome, in addition to the proposal before us, the proposal on the use of SME growth markets. Just as improved access to the capital market will make it easier for companies to seek financing there, the appropriate cross-border distribution of investment funds will enable financial service providers to take up their important role as intermediaries.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, firstly, my sympathies on hearing about the fire at Notre Dame Cathedral. It is really very sad – a beautiful cathedral. Now to the report. The smooth distribution of EU cross-border investment funds is hindered by national regulatory barriers. Of the EUR 14.3 trillion investment fund, 70% of total assets under management are held by funds authorised or registered for distribution only in the domestic market. Only 37% of UCITS and about 3% of alternative investment funds are currently registered for distribution in more than three Member States. This makes a Capital Markets Union rather meaningless. So four years on, this flagship project will finally reduce some barriers, increase transparency and remove overly complex and burdensome national rules. It is a win for the investors, getting more choice, better value and protection. I welcome this reform as a critical step. However, to ensure, say that a Portuguese retail investor can be fully confident in investing in Latvian investment products, more work needs to be done in terms of the fees charged. My question to the Vice-President is: are there any preparations for greater transparency and standardisation on the capping of the fees charged?

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Madam President, there is a desperate lack of both venture capital and own investment from collective investment funds in Europe. As my colleague Neena Gill already said, at the moment, compared with the USA or compared with Asian countries, our situation is close to meaningless because Member States are setting different kinds of rules because of the cost structure and because marketing regulations are very opaque. The investors have not dared to really take up the Capital Markets Union. So I really do welcome this piece of legislation that actually, hopefully, opens things up by setting clearer rules for pre-marketing and marketing regulation, and thus also improves consumer protection. The next steps that should be taken are creating fully fledged European supervision, and then a greater transparency on cost structures.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, once again I would like to thank the rapporteur Mr Klinz and the shadow rapporteurs for their commitment. I look forward to the vote tomorrow, which should pave the way for a swift entry into force of this legislative package. We estimate up to EUR 440 million in cost savings for fund managers thanks to our measures. This will accelerate the growth of the single market for investment funds, boost competition between asset managers and ultimately give more choice at lower costs for investors.

name: Peter SIMON
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, thank you very much for the excellent cooperation in two and a half years – two and a half years, which were marked by the balance of interests, the merging of completely different ideas. Ideas about how we make Europe safer, how, after the banking crisis of 2008, which cost the taxpayer EUR 2 000 billion, we are getting the world out of the firing line. In addition to the rapporteurs Othmar Karas, mrs Caroline Nagtegaal from the ALDE, Sven Giegold from the Greens, Ashley Fox and the other rapporteurs, I would like to thank the staff of the European Commission and Vice-President Dombrovskis in particular. We have been fortunate here that the Commission, in difficult negotiations, in difficult times with its staff – and this can be said – was available day and night to help us find the best possible compromise here. And what we have achieved is impressive: we have introduced key elements here in banking supervision, implementing what the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision has laid down, which have not yet existed. We have introduced a leverage ratio, i.e. a reduction in banks' debt, a backstop for a capital under-ceiling. We have put a premium on global systemically important banks. By introducing a structural liquidity ratio, we have introduced the safeguarding of banks' long-term liquidity and solvency. By implementing the TLAC standard, we have ensured that ailing banks, especially large international banks, can be wound up in the future and that the taxpayer does not have to go, and, and, and. Personally, however, it was particularly important to me that, for the first time, we introduced a principle that, for me, is a bridgehead for the future, which is to be built in the coming years, something that ensures that we have a level playing field for all banks in Europe. , but not by equal rules for all, but by differentiation. In the past, we have failed to take account of the fact that small, low-risk, local banks should be treated differently from large, internationally riskier banks. We have failed in the past to ensure that they are relieved of bureaucracy where possible and not to be burdened. With this report – and Here I am grateful to all my colleagues – we have managed for the first time that all banks that are less than five billion and who can demonstrate in terms of quality that they are low-risk have so much red-scale relief that, hopefully, we will not be able to hear in future that the result of over-bureaucratisation is forced mergers, because small banks simply did not get to the brink of the current rules. With our ideas for a single European reporting system, We have hopefully managed for the future, that there is reliability, when banks of a smaller nature and others are confronted with queries which in the past have led to the need to meet the requests of different institutions and institutions on Mondays, Tuesdays and Wednesdays, and then perhaps on Thursdays we could perhaps start to do normal work. Making it safer, on the one hand, but taking into account the diversity of the risk profile of banks in Europe on the other – that was our task. And I believe that we, together with all the parties here who have worked constructively on this, have achieved this with the European Commission and, in the end, even after many long and difficult meetings with the Member States. I would like to thank all my fellow Members once again, as well as the staff of the Commission.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank all the colleagues, the shadows, the Commission and the Council for all the good work we have done and what we have achieved. Regarding the banking crisis, we have in reality succeeded with three different legislations: first of all, the hierarchy, which we decided upon a year ago, and now the two legislations for the Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation (SRMR) and the Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive (BRRD). This is built upon the Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive that was adopted in 2014. One of the fundamental aims of that was to change the logic of the banking sector, to clarify that those who own a bank or invest in a bank have full responsibility when bad times come. Together with the tools of a bridge bank or mergers of banks, we added the bail-in procedure, meaning that, if you have invested in the bank, you also risk losing the capital you have invested. This is something we have in order to achieve two fundamentally-important things: first of all to clarify to everyone that you have risk when investing in a bank. The other one is to ensure that you can do the bail-in procedure in a foreseeable and certain way. For me as the rapporteur of the BRRD from the beginning, and now with these legislations, it has been extremely important to stick to that rule, to ensure that the introduction of TLAC (total loss-absorbing capacity) is not a way of circumventing the fact that all capital in a bank is to be seen as ‘bail-in-able: that is, creating a market discipline and helping taxpayers in all the different events that can come. This also means that we have achieved better rules regarding how to set the TLAC in Minimum Requirement for own funds and Eligible Liabilities (MREL). I’m happy that we achieved a discretionary cap from Parliament’s side, meaning that you don’t punish banks with a high level of own capital, but also meaning that you can set the level of MREL and TLAC depending on the risk structure of the bank. This is what we have achieved and I think that we are now facing the fact that, if I may phrase it that way, never have we had such good opportunities for those who will have the responsibility to resolve banks in bad times, because this means that this will be easier – we are facilitating that – but it also means that the markets will be much more alert and avoid banking getting into crisis. That is, of course, the most important thing. The fact that everyone who invests in a bank now knows that you are risking something means that we will have thousands and thousands of supervisors securing that you have the right level of capital and the right level of MREL in the banks they are providing capital to. I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs and the Commission, who have helped us through with this. We now have a very good foundation for the banking union and we have a very good foundation for the European economy.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, the banking package legislative proposal was adopted by the Commission almost two-and-a-half years ago in November 2016. The proposal built on existing EU banking rules aimed to complete the post-crisis regulatory agenda. The proposal was a major step in risk reduction, and also fulfilled our international commitments by implementing internationally agreed standards, while ensuring that banks can continue to support the real economy. The Council reached a general approach in May 2018 after intensive negotiations of three consecutive presidencies, the European Parliament followed in June 2018, and political agreement was reached in December. So I’d like to take this opportunity to thank the honourable Members involved in negotiating this package for their commitment and their political will to reach a compromise, and in particular the rapporteurs, Mr Simon and Mr Hökmark. Your efforts and dedication were instrumental in reaching this agreement. Parliament helped to improve several elements of the original Commission proposal. You enriched the package with additional elements that were absent in the initial proposal, for example in the areas of sustainable finance and anti-money laundering. The package on which you will vote tomorrow includes important measures to strengthen the resilience of banks. For instance, it introduces a binding leverage ratio as a backstop to prevent institutions from excessive leverage, and it establishes a binding net stable funding ratio to address excessive reliance on short-term wholesale funding. The package will also enhance the rules on governance and supervision of banks and will give macro-prudential supervisors additional flexibility to address macro-prudential risks more effectively. In addition, the new rules also improve the resolvability of banks when they are in difficulties. In particular, the new rules transpose into EU law the international total loss-absorbing capacity standard applicable to globally systemically important institutions. This will set a harmonised minimum requirement for own funds and eligible liabilities (MREL) that has to be met with capital or debt instruments of high quality and, together with numerous other enhancements, this will ensure that banks are building robust buffers that can be used in case of resolution so as to avoid a spillover on public finances and ensure a clear and transparent process vis-à-vis banks, authorities and the markets. At the same time, the package pays close attention to a number of issues that matter to the financing of the real economy. Your agreed rules improve banks’ lending capacity to support the real economy. In particular, they enhance capacity to lend to SMEs and to fund infrastructure projects. In this sense, these aspects are very much in line with our jobs and growth agenda. The package also injects more proportionality into the prudential framework for banks. It will reduce the administrative burden stemming from reporting, disclosure and remuneration requirements for small non-complex banks, and in areas where we introduce new standards, we have calibrated simple but conservative alternatives for small non-complex banks which they can use. The package will introduce for the first time the considerations of environmental, social and governance risks in bank prudential regulation, for example through the obligation for large listed banks to disclose the environmental and social risks they are exposed to. And last, but not least, following the recent money laundering scandals you included measures to enhance cooperation and information exchange between prudential and AML supervisory authorities and the European Banking Authority’s role in this context, together with the ESA review, those are important steps. This package constitutes a major step in completing the European post-crisis regulatory reform. All of these reforms together will make our banks more stable and solid. So it’s a very important step forward in risk reduction and now it’s time to move also on risk-sharing. We need to implement the agreement on the backstop to the Single Resolution Fund, and we need to move forward with the discussions on a European deposit insurance scheme.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has For the time being, I would like to thank Peter Simon and Gunnar Hökmark, all the shadow rapporteurs, the Commission, but also our staff. Together with the new banking regulation, we have taken an important step towards the completion of the Banking Union. This is the biggest risk bureaucracy and cost reduction in European banking regulation.  We have achieved this with six key points: firstly, a tougher own resources requirement that takes account of the structural characteristics of the European banking sector. Secondly, for the first time, there is a definition of proportionality between small and non-complex institutions, including qualitative criteria. Thirdly, we are creating significant administrative facilitation and 20% less regulatory costs for small banks. Fourthly, there will be even greater support for the real economy through the development of the so-called SME factor from EUR 1.5 million to EUR 2.5 million. Fifthly, the scheme also provides an answer to digitalisation by favouring software investments. Sixthly, the creation of a single European register of registration will lead to an end to the duplicate reporting obligations. We have therefore contributed, on the one hand, to stabilising the financial market and, on the other, protecting smaller banks. In doing so, we have strengthened Europe as a business location and achieved great success for the European Parliament. Thank you very much for the excellent cooperation.

name: Ralph PACKET
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, it is of course very important that risks remain under control in our banking sector and that sufficient buffers are put in place to deal with setbacks. Because that way we will not be able to get into a scenario like that of ten years ago, when a crisis in the financial sector dragged the entire economy into a deep recession. We are satisfied with the reforms, although the international agreements for us should be adopted even more strictly. The main problem, however, is not the new regulation and supervision, but the mountain of bad debts that have not been cleared up in some countries after ten years. There's work to be done there. Start it, otherwise those debts will hang over this generation and the next generations.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report After the banks had to be bailed out with EUR 100 billion in taxpayers' money during the financial crisis caused by the banks, one of the aims of European policy was to stop spending taxpayers' money on bailing out banks in the future and also to limit the power of megabanks.  Unfortunately, this amendment to the Bank Restructuring and Resolution Directive does not achieve this objective. Instead of requiring banks to have high and simple capital ratios, they have turned to complicated capital requirements with a number of exemptions in order to protect the banking sector. It has refrained from separating risky investment banking from the credit and deposit business.  And instead of finally tackling the too-big-to-fail problem and shrinking big banks, German SPD Finance Minister Olaf Scholz, among others, dreams of merging the two wobbly giants Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank, which would then have a combined balance sheet total of just under two trillion euros. But two old Opels don't make a Ferrari together. The stability of the banking sector would be disserviced with this merger.  The weaknesses of the resolution mechanism have also been disclosed several times in practice in recent years. One wonders what a serious creditor allocation should only look like in times of crisis, when this policy fails even in comparatively quiet times. We do not need national champions and megabanks, but more boring banking, which is geared to the needs of the real economy.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: au nom du groupe Verts/ALE. Madame la Présidente, je trouve ce débat surréaliste. Notre-Dame is on fire! I honestly don't like to talk about banking rules now. For me, this Church is a symbol of our culture in Europe, one of the most glorious churches of Christianity. I hope that at least the firefighters who are on duty now will not be harmed. What is happening is a tragedy for European culture. All I can say is that I find this discussion rather crazy.

name: Caroline NAGTEGAAL
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, the credit crisis is still fresh in our minds. Governments had to keep banks afloat and Europeans had to tighten their belts.
