Distrust in the financial sector has never been higher. I think everyone in this Chamber agrees with me when I say that we do not want to find ing another situation like this. Fortunately, we have ... this package, which involves many measures to prevent us from going to the wrong. So if we vote in favour of the plan, banks will have to keep more money in their reserves from now on. So the so-called bank buffers are going up further in Europe. That's a good thing. But at the same time, our task is not yet complete. Too many banks still have far too many non-outstanding loans on their balance sheets. If the electorate gives me confidence again, that is what I will be fighting for in the next five years. Rules for banks need to be tightened when it comes to loans that are worth nothing or almost nothing. Moreover, I think banks should be more cautious when it comes to the government bonds they have. Because if countries do not have their act together, it should have no effect on banks and certainly not on savers. Let's face it, banks are not our enemies. In my view, they are indispensable for a good economic climate. They help us tackle terrorism and other crimes, and to help us make it more sustainable and to finance innovative ideas. But I do want the bad apples from the system to be dealt with.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about a package called risk reduction within the European banking system. What I wonder is whether, in fact, we are convinced that we have reduced the risks within the European banking system and the most important risks.  In other words, what I have been saying for five years now in this Parliament, the greatest risk is in liquid securities held by European systemic banks. Liquid securities are derivatives, they are securities that have difficulty being then also valued by supervision and in the event of a crisis they can really lose so much value in a short time. And these securities from vigilance and not even from these rules are put under a magnifying glass, and this is a serious mistake that we will most likely pay dearly. And the biggest mistake, which is behind risk reduction, is to focus the will to want to reduce risks only on the credit side. Credit is the lifeblood of the European economy, small and medium-sized enterprises, families, those who want to buy a house, machinery and so on. The fact that a bank is being restricting credit to the extent that it is being asked to provide too many capital requirements, very often, in an excessive way, suffice it to say that, despite the existing requirements, the BRRD review asks banks to go and place additional securities on the market in order to obtain more capital in the event of a bail-in, and the resolution authorities will also be able to ask the banks to increase these requirements.  And I want to figure out now who has the money in one of these banks will feel confident that they're going to keep it in there, to the extent that an authority will ask this bank to go to the market and ask for capital requirements.  That is what is being done is a great disaster in my view, the whole structure of the Banking Union should be clearly reviewed, because it creates major imbalances and creates strong disaffection on the part of citizens towards European policy.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D- Madam President, the bailout of the banks is essential and, fortunately, after the financial crisis, the Basel Committee and the Committee on Financial Stabilization have helped to improve the system. Today we are integrating this into European law to reduce the risks that could develop within our banking system. We are strengthening the framework for resolving bank failures. We are strengthening controls on systemically important institutions, in terms of their ability to absorb losses and the need for recapitalization, with requirements in terms of the level and quality of capital and eligible commitments, this is the famous MREL. We are also introducing interim safeguards and possible additional measures for the resolution authorities.  The package will also tighten prudential standards to reduce incentives for excessive risk-taking by providing for a short-term liquidity ratio, leverage ratio and, finally, a stable net financing ratio. It will improve banks' lending capacity to finance infrastructure projects and take into account environmental criteria, as well as the need to promote gender equality in management bodies. However, this package will not solve everything, it is only a step. We have to go further and if we have a banking union, there is no reason why we should not get the full consequences. This means that the benefits of this unique jurisdiction must be fully recognized in the granting of exemptions in cross-border transactions.  Similarly, the principle of proportionality should not ignore the actual nature of the risks taken depending on the size of the models in a particular market. Finally, after years of bank bailouts, it is time to move towards more solidarity and finally adopt this much-promised European deposit guarantee for European savers.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has After the financial and economic crisis, financial stability was rightly the focus of the legislator. After all, it was a question of ensuring that a crisis such as the one we experienced ten years ago cannot be repeated. We have lost sight of the fact that not every bank is Lehman Brothers. Not every bank is as big and as closely intertwined as Lehman Brothers, and not every bank has a business model as risky as Lehman Brothers. The opposite is true: most banks in the European Union are non-cross-border investment banks with a huge trading book full of repeatedly leveraged derivative positions. Nevertheless, we have for a long time pretended that all banks were the same and should be subject to exactly the same rules. It should be clear that equal rules for all do not mean equal effort for everyone. With the banking package, we are doing things differently for the first time. For the first time, we have defined what is a small and non-complex institution on the basis of clear qualitative and quantitative criteria and therefore regulatory facilitation should be accompanied by this classification. In doing so, we ensure proportionality in banking regulation and bring life under this concept. We must build on this success, especially when we are dealing with the finalisation of Basel III in the coming parliamentary term. Here, too, we must revisit the idea of proportionality.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, this new banking regulatory package is very important. The aim is to strengthen the soundness of the European financial system so that it can withstand shocks, gain confidence and stop being a permanent threat to depositors and taxpayers. European rules on bank recovery and resolution now meet the most stringent international standards and banks, especially the largest ones, will have to increase their own funds by strengthening their ability to bear losses. These rules will only come into force after a transitional period, which will allow banks to adapt to new requirements without undermining their ability to finance the real economy. I would like to thank the rapporteurs Gunnar Hökmark and Peter Simon for the good work and good cooperation we have had in these risk reduction measures in the banking sector. It is now time to move forward in risk sharing without which there will be no banking union worthy of that name.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, reform in the banking sector was certainly necessary after the huge crisis that has hit societies over the last decade. Of course, the conclusion is that the taxpayers rescued the banks and then the banks — especially in Greece — fell on the taxpayers, on the Greek people, in order to supposedly regulate the red loans and so the "crows" grab the homes of the Greek people. There is certainly a need for increased supervision, differentiated supervision for smaller banks, but there also needs to be control and supervision. I would like to see control to see the relationship that banks have with the media, with those who have radios and televisions, especially in Greece, as well as with polling companies. We see that in the run-up to the European elections, those who speak out against the banks are excluded from the media in Greece, as in the case of our "Greece - The Other Way" movement. Check who has taken out loans, from the media, in Greece.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Madam President, I welcome many of the important developments in the Capital Requirements Package, such as the new anti-money laundering provisions and restrictions on pay and dividends for breaches of capital requirements. The introduction of TLAC (total loss-absorbing capacity) has been hailed by some as a sufficient solution to solve the problem of too-big-to-fail banks, but I don’t believe that’s possible without bank structural reform and a larger binding leverage ratio. The Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive has already been proven to be ineffective at preventing tax payer-funded bailouts. From the beginning of the process of negotiating the package, we have expressed serious concerns over the capital leverage ratio being set at just 3%. We should remember that the OECD and the US Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation recommend a leverage ratio of at least 5% for institutions that are systematically important. So we are allowing, effectively, EU banks’ desire to compete with their American counterparts to put financial stability at risk. Finally, we’ll never be able to separate the too-big-to-fail problem from bank structural reform. The most effective way to achieve the objective of risk reduction is to separate retail from investment banking. The fact that, a decade after the financial crisis, legislators have failed to achieve this is an absolute indictment, in my view, on all EU institutions and a total failure to meet the expectations that European citizens had placed in us all.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madame la Présidente, mes premières pensées sont pour les Français et les Françaises, les Parisiens et les Parisiennes confrontés à ce terrible incendie qui se produit ce soir à Notre-Dame. Il s’agit d’une terrible nouvelle, c’est une journée noire pour la culture européenne et je voudrais tout simplement exprimer ma solidarité aux pompiers et aux services qui font leur maximum pour essayer d’éteindre cet incendie le plus rapidement possible. I would like to just take the few seconds I have left to thank Mr Hökmark for the excellent work we have done together. I think that we have important levels for the minimum requirement for own funds and eligible liabilities (MREL) and total loss absorbing capacity (TLAC) that will avoid us having to use taxpayers’ money again in the next crisis. I think we have made progress and I would like particularly to thank him for accepting our proposals on consumer protection, and avoiding having small savers trapped in a bail-in process as we have had in the past. I think we have successfully achieved that in the text and I would like to thank him for that.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Madam President, my deepest sorrow for the destruction of the cultural heritage, not only for Parisians and France, but for all of us Europeans. This is the completion of the big package after what we did after the financial crisis to stabilise banking risks and resolving mechanisms and the adequate capital requirements. I would like to thank and congratulate the rapporteurs for doing a great job on this. But I would like to remind the Commission and the upcoming Parliament of two challenges that we still have ahead of us. One is the so-called Liikanen package, and that refers to the firewalls between the retail banking and investment banking, and the other part is that the banks and lending should be part of the sustainable finance, because there we have a broiling financial crisis and risks that are embedded in sunk investments in fossil fuels, for example.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Madam President, indeed the news from Paris is mesmerising and sad.  At the end of the mandate, we also wonder whether we have learned the lessons from the financial crisis. For one, we don’t have a European Volcker rule separating retail and investment bankers and we still need to finish the banking union with the European deposit insurance scheme (EDIS) and banks are still vulnerable and undercapitalised. Therefore, I am pleased with this regulation as it is very much forward-looking.  Under the new rules, a systemically relevant bank must have significantly more funds to strengthen the principle of bail-in, and that’s good. The new rules also anticipate the change towards sustainable finance, giving the EBA a role in assessing risk for people and planet. Indeed, we need a solid and forward—looking framework, learning the lessons from the crisis and anticipating new developments. The package is a welcome step, but it’s still part of a work in progress.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Former German President Horst Köhler has seen the cause of the recent global financial crisis in the underpricing of risk. Governments and banks, especially in the southern periphery of the eurozone, have taken too much risks because real interest rates were negative there from 2002 to 2007. When interest rates rose again, these states were over-indebted. At the same time, their banks had become distressed. A vicious circle! The Deutsche Bundesbank shows a way out of this vicious circle.  The purchase of government bonds is not risk-free, so such bonds should be backed up with equity. But then the states will have to pay higher interest rates to offset the risk premium. They reject that. So there is still an underpricing of risk.  The day comes when the vicious circle of over-indebted states and distressed banks is becoming a reality and monetary union is dragging its way into the abyss. I know that Kassandra's warnings are blown away, but unfortunately she is right.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Madam President, it has been more than a decade on the financial crisis of 2008. Four billion euros were spent on public funds to recapitalise banking. In Portugal it was 16 billion euros, ten percent of GDP.  After eleven years on the crisis, after dozens of regulations, of directives, the question is: what were the concrete advances? Because in Portugal, we are perplexed because the tap remains open. €2 billion was spent on the new bank in 2018 and 2019, and the current Government Stability Programme is expected to be an additional €2.15 billion for 2020 and 2021.  Let us be clear, these directives, these regulations are just pure cosmetics. What is really needed is public control over the financial system to put banks at the service of the economy and not the economy at the service of banks, as is clearly the case.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is still a long way to go to complete the Banking Union, and it requires concrete political initiatives to prevent and limit future banking crises. Member States should, for example, ensure sufficient absorption of losses by financial institutions in order to minimise their impact on financial stability and taxpayers. It would be important to have competent authorities, with powers of immediate intervention to support financial institutions in difficulty, just as it would be necessary to create cross-border markets in which all consumers can benefit from the positive effects of an integrated European banking system. Finally, more attention should be paid to the assessment of risks related to the environment and social issues, favouring measures to address these risks in an appropriate manner. The new rules all go in this direction, will make it possible to reduce risks in the financial system, while ensuring that banks play a more active role in promoting growth, development and investment.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would also like to express my shock at the terrible fire in Notre Dame de Paris. It’s a landmark not only for Paris or France; it’s a landmark for the whole of Europe and the world, so indeed it’s very sad to see it going down in flames. Moving back to the Banking Package. The Banking Reform Package represents an important step towards further reducing risks in the financial sector. So I’d like to, once again, thank you for your support expressed in this House for this package. Subject to your endorsement of this package tomorrow, the risk reductions contained in it would not only strengthen the resilience of Europe’s banking system and increase market confidence, but they will also pave the way for further progress in the completion of the Banking Union, such as delivering a much-needed common backstop to the Single Resolution Fund. I am happy to see this important piece of work delivered and finalised, and I am confident it will contribute to making our financial sector more robust and stable, and I hope it will pave the way for further progress towards deepening the Economic and Monetary Union. Therefore, I encourage you to endorse the political agreement tomorrow and, once again, thank you to the rapporteurs.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, first of all to Madam Berès and to our French colleagues, sad news from Paris, sad news for us all, because Notre-Dame is Notre Dame – in history and all the sagas, but also as a cultural landmark for Europe, and that remains very strong. Madam President, regarding the banking package. A lot of things have already been said here tonight, but I think it’s fair to say that now the landscape is different. The European banking sector is today much more robust but also much more ready to act when there is a crisis. And there will come new crises. The question is just how we are able to deal with them, and I’m convinced that with the introduction of the BRRD, as we have decided here in Parliament, and the revision we are going to decide upon now, with a hierarchy and with the TLAC, and with its discretionary opportunities for competent authorities: things are better. That doesn’t mean that all the problems ahead of us are solved, but I think we have created the mechanism for those who are responsible in each and every situation to do the best they can in order to solve those situations. I must also say that I’m happy to achieve this. This is, Madam President, the last report I’ll be presenting to this plenary, and I feel proud that we have achieved this together, and I have a lot of admiration for all the colleagues here, from all sorts of tribes, all sorts of political colours and coming from all parts of Europe. It has for me been a fantastic 15 years in this Parliament, and I’m looking forward to following it from my sofa.

name: Peter SIMON
text: Rapporteur. – (Beginning of the speech with the microphone switched off) Although each of the colleagues who could speak here had a very narrow speaking time, in many speeches the news of the Fire of the Notre-Dame World Heritage Site was the subject of the new message we received. The object is to express solidarity with France and our French colleagues here. It is precisely in this spirit that we have been working together for two and a half years, and this is the spirit in which this House is working together. If we look at where the major criticisms came from today, if we look at extremes from the left to the right, I note one thing today: at the end of the debate, almost all of the critics are no longer there, but those who have worked together constructively for two and a half years are still here today. And that can guide the work of the future House, because the work is not yet finished. With the implementation of Basel IV – that is, the finalisation of Basel III – we are getting to a point where this House must show its colours here: are we continuing along the path taken towards greater security and higher risk pricing, while at the same time easing the burden on those who have not contributed to the cause of the last crisis and who are still stable and low-risk today? I believe that, in the spirit that has shaped the last two and a half years, we are looking at what are each other's needs, what are the needs that need to be taken into account here? – if we take this into account together in a spirit of solidarity, if we stabilise banks but not at the expense of our neighbours, if we want security for all of us and balanced interests across Europe, I believe that there will continue to be good further cooperation and a safer financial system in Europe in the future.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, April 16, 2019. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. – In addition to the aspects addressed in the previous regulations on capital requirements, the Directive contains a number of new elements. In order to prevent banks from incentivising their employees to take excessive risks, the Regulation provides for a maximum ratio between fixed and variable remuneration for all employees concerned. The bonus may not exceed the fixed annual remuneration of the identified employee, unless the shareholders decide, under certain conditions, to allow bonuses equal to this amount up to twice the fixed remuneration. The new rules also include requirements for bonuses that promote long-term risk-taking. The Regulation also introduces rules to ensure effective supervision by banks' governing bodies and to improve risk management. The composition of the members of the Board of Management requires diversity in order to contribute to effective supervision. The regulation also reduces the dependence of credit institutions on external ratings. Thus, all banks' investment decisions must be based not only on ratings, but on their own internal creditworthiness. I agree with the new capital requirements. I particularly welcome the fact that the agreement includes both increased requirements for large financial institutions and simplified requirements for small and non-complex institutions, particularly with regard to reporting.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the debate on the report by Jons Fernandez, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the european Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on sovereign bond-backed securities (COM(2018)0339 - C8-0206/2018 - 2018/0171 (COD)) (A8-0180/2019).

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Vice-President of the Dombrovskis Commission, the truth is that it is difficult to keep this debate tonight following the news coming to us from Paris with this terrible fire which is ravaging one of the cultural references of our continent, of our Europe, in this increasingly complicated and difficult world. In any case, we have this debate, this last debate on the Rules of Procedure to create a securitisation of public debt prior to tomorrow's vote, on a proposal for a Regulation which the Commission has been presenting some time ago and which has been really difficult. I would like to thank, first of all, the support and closeness and spirit of collaboration of all the rapporteurs in the various groups, because, as I said, it has not been easy to be able to move this proposal for a Regulation until we reached an agreement, validated in our committee a few weeks ago and which tomorrow I hope you will get the broad support of this House. We were now discussing the banking package, which we will also vote on tomorrow, and the need for a safer banking system to avoid bailouts or fiscal crises in the future. But what we are going to discuss now, and we will vote tomorrow, too, is how to avoid fiscal crises like the ones we experienced in 2010 and 2012, because these bailouts created public deficits and those public deficits made it difficult to place public debt from many states, some of which ended up having to call a bailout on the European institutions. It is important to have a secure banking sector, but it is also very important not only to have secure national accounts but also to have instruments to combat and combat these public debt liquidity crises that we suffered in 2010 and 2012. And I believe that the Commission proposal we discussed in this Parliament was a well-oriented proposal, and I also believe that this Parliament has succeeded in improving it. It has managed to give the European authorities greater capacity to monitor these securitisations of public debt, we have given ESMA greater powers, greater supervisory capacity for such products, and I believe that we have improved, in turn, the quality of that senior stretch which is called to become, at least in the short term , in insurance, in a risk-free asset, in a European secure asset that in turn allows banks' balance sheets to be diversified. As I say, negotiation has been difficult in recent months, but we have reached a very broad agreement in this Parliament, aimed at ending the reform of the euro area in the face of the need for instruments that make it difficult, that make it unworkable to live crises like the ones we experienced in 2010 and 1012. It is important to have a secure banking sector, as we have discussed now, but it is also very important to have tools to enable States to deal with future crises without the need to embark on pro-cyclical adjustment programmes that end up worsening Europe's economic circumstances. And so it's a step forward, it's a determined step, but we have a lot to do. We have much work to do to achieve a stable, future-facing euro area with resilience to future crises.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, it is good to have this important debate today on Sovereign Bond-Backed Securities.  Sovereign Bond-Backed Securities, or SBBS as they are known, are a novel instrument — constructed out of euro area sovereign bonds through pooling and tranching — that could help us advance towards a more complete Banking Union and a more efficient and integrated Capital Market Union. They could in fact boost private sector risk sharing, especially across borders, and equip banks with an additional tool to diversify their sovereign exposures. This would further weaken the nexus between banks and their own sovereign — which proved a major source of vulnerability in the euro area debt crisis.  As you know, the existing regulatory framework includes some obstacles to SBBS, in that they would be at a regulatory disadvantage vis-à-vis euro area sovereign bonds. Our May 2018 proposal aims at enabling them, basically by granting them same regulatory treatment as for sovereign bonds. Importantly, SBBS would, by design, not involve any mutualisation or transfer of risks among Member States, as they are a purely private sector instrument for private sector use.  And I also want to stress that our proposal does not alter in any way the regulatory treatment of euro-area sovereign bonds, rather our proposal takes such regulatory as a give. I also want to stress here that our proposal does not alter in any way the regulatory treatment of euro area sovereign bonds. Rather, our proposal takes such regulatory treatment as a given. I would like to commend the rapporteur for this file, Mr Jonás Fernández and all colleagues in the ECON committee for their steadfast efforts on this file, which allowed a supportive vote on 21 March this year and I am of the view that a supportive vote by this plenary session, coming on the heels of the positive vote in the ECON Committee, would send a strong signal to the Council about the importance that both the Commission and Parliament attribute to this file and this should lead the Council to give renewed priority to this file.

name: Stefan GEHROLD
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has This proposal to remove regulatory barriers to the market-driven development of securities is an important contribution to the stability of our financial system. Firstly, the proposed rules create greater security, secondly, they create a higher degree of integration – this is particularly important compared to potentially other products – and, thirdly, they create fewer risks for public budgets. Risks are transferred to the private sector by the proposal and at the same time help investors to diversify their investment holdings across Europe and to promote the networking of European financial markets. A hasty and ill-considered communitarisation of risks or losses is avoided. I see a valuable approach in the proposed regulation to build on the foundations laid after the financial crisis. This proposal creates a pragmatic solution that makes it possible to pursue the development with determination, but avoids overshooting the target and thereby jeopardising the stability of the markets as a whole in the long term. I would sometimes like to see that understood in other areas. So do we have the courage to think long-term and to initiate sustainable growth measures with the necessary patience!

name: Ralph PACKET
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, I also find it very difficult to speak here while Notre-Dame is in a state of emergency. This affects all of us. It is a historic disaster, a cultural disaster for the whole of Europe. Now there is a proposal here to make our financial system safer. It is, of course, the case that banks are too closely linked to their government. But we are not going to solve that problem with complex, synthetic financial products that only increase the financial stability of the euro area. Because that's kind of the trick that's been used in the United States: repackage all kinds of junk mortgages with good products, and spread them further. It was thought that the risks disappeared as a result. There has been a serious mistake in this. Due to a lack of transparency and a high correlation between these different markets, this would increase the risk of infection between countries in times of crisis. There is a great danger of chain reaction in the event of a crisis and better measures are needed to improve our banking system.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, friend Jonah and other colleagues, I obviously cannot begin this little address without saying that today a part of Europe's soul has been squea over. I offer my condolences not to my French friends, but to all Europeans.  And that gives me the point of saying that we have built other things with great effort, as Notre-Dame was, as the European Union has been and it has been the euro, and that they are also enormously fragile; and that we have continued to have lost an almost entire mandate without properly propping up the euro.  That is why this attempt by the Commission and that great work done by Jonah and the shadow rapporteurs is very welcome so that, in alDE's view, there will be a linked European asset, tied up, supporting the single currency which is the euro.  There is talk of mutualization, we talk... that's really boycotting. There's nothing mutualizing—and I'm sorry, but there isn't. And there's talk that the market won't want it... Well, let this attempt work, let's see what the market says.  It is a European product that supports europe's single currency, which involves asset diversification, which is a possible lightening for debt-strangled countries – sovereign debt – which has a subsequent effect on the possibility of improving social policies, for example.  It is an attempt, despite all the obstacles, to start creating a better and stronger euro with backup financial assets, which we have managed not to set aside, not to marginalize any Eurogroup state — none of them! – because otherwise it would have failed in its objective.  That the Franco-German axis doesn't like it? Well, let them propose something better. And if not, please: the head high, because we have taken out something that can proudly claim the euro.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Having only just a few minutes ago discussed and discussed the consequences of the financial crisis for the banking sector, I am once again astonished by the seemingly excessive confidence of this House in the stability of the financial markets. The last financial crisis is not so long ago, and we should all remember the consequences of unbridled speculation on securitised financial products.  And just as securitised mortgages have not made the financial system more stable in the past, securitised government bonds, i.e. sovereign bond-backed securities, will not be able to make the eurozone more stable, quite the contrary. They, too, are threatening to increase the instability of financial markets in the event of a crisis. They will not be able to help prevent the flight to safe facilities, nor will they help to correct the eurozone's design flaws. SBBS are thus merely a tinkering with the symptom, but not correcting the causes.  The political conflicts, and also the design flaws that are currently hindering a stable monetary union, cannot be circumvented by financial alchemy and technical trickery.  If we want a stable eurozone, we need a central bank that guarantees the government bonds of its members. Germany & Co. must stop digging the water out of their partner countries with their unfair economic policies. We need public investment in economically structurally weaker regions. This would also pave the way for genuine European bonds.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking and congratulating Jonás Fernández. It wasn't easy to get this forward, you have to admit it. And I think a good job has been done. My group obviously believes that this is not the solution to the structural problems that the euro has. BTDS is not the substitute for Eurobonds and we still need a fiscal capacity worthy of such a name, so this is not going to get us out of the shortcomings of design. However, I would like to thank Mr Fernández for accepting some of the proposals we have made to him in relation to the BTDS and that we believed to be important. For example, to provide ESMA with the capacity to clearly monitor the liquidity of sovereign debt markets so that the creation of THE BTDS cannot have negative effects, so that ESMA can control that.  And second, too, that the European Systemic Risk Board can play an important role in macroprudential control of this new market that we are going to create. I would therefore like once again to thank Mr Fernandez for his work and for the good work in this negotiation.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, once again the European Union is engineering ways to support the financial sector by reducing the risk to banks by developing securities on the market secured by government bonds. Unfortunately, gentlemen, we've seen the play before. In Greece, bondholders who had invested in buying government bonds saw the labors of a lifetime evaporate overnight. Many Greek investors saw their properties lose 53.5% of their value, while the loss today exceeds 75%.  On 12 March 2012, with the famous PSI for the haircut of Greek debt, which was essentially done to rescue European banks, in addition to small investors, they also lost the Greek insurance funds around 12 billion euros. This was the principle by which, at the suggestion of the lenders and with the cooperation of the willing Greek governments, pensions, main and subsidiary, welfare benefits, equity and solidarity funds were reduced. Once again it has been confirmed that the wrong policies of the Union are paid for by the citizens of European states.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the financial crisis has created too many problems, especially in Greece. We had the famous PSI, the "haircut" of government bonds, which led to the poverty of thousands of micro-bondholders, who at the moment have no money even for medical care. At the same time, the government bonds held by the insurance funds were also "tired". The damage exceeded 12 billion euros. But who was excluded? The bonds held by the European Central Bank were excluded and the European Central Bank won and the Greek economy was dissolved. The problems of the euro area are not dealt with with aspirin, as is this proposal, nor with state guarantees of various bonds to be issued by the banks. It needs a change in the structure of the euro area; it must be a eurozone that serves all peoples and not German Europe.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would again like to express my thanks for the work on the proposed enabling regulatory framework for sovereign bond—backed securities. As I said earlier, I hope that this important file can gain a renewed momentum, including with the Council.  The Commission has taken good note of the modifications that Parliament has proposed. We will now study them very carefully with a view to engaging in fruitful discussions, also with the Council, in the period ahead. So, once again I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Fernández, and I thank you for today’s debate.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, good night again. Simply take advantage of these two minutes to sincerely thank all the rapporteurs for their work on this Regulation... that, as we said, we started negotiating with several rejection amendments and in a situation we could say that complex. But the truth is that in recent months all groups have shown a clear vocation to reach an agreement and I believe that we have succeeded.  I would like to thank, in turn, the work of my colleague Jakob von Weizs-cker, who has been the rapporteur for much of last year and that without him and without his work and without the conduct of these negotiations — until it was my turn to take up this responsibility — we would not have been able to get here.  I believe that Parliament fires a legislature with a great job. I believe that today's debates and tomorrow's votes, with all these regulations and directives in the Committee on Economic and Economic Affairs, show that Parliament is committed to advancing the euro area.  And I think it is very important that this vote on a regulation which takes a step further in the construction of that monetary union, of that stable euro area — which obviously we are not able to move forward with everything we should, but we continue to walk - I believe, as I say, that Parliament is giving a lesson in European commitment to work, of compromise.  And let us hope that in the next parliamentary term the Council will have just made progress, inter alia in this Regulation, because Parliament is already ready to start negotiations and we hope that the Council will be able to reach some agreement in the coming months.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed.  The vote will take place on Tuesday, 16 April 2019.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the joint debate on: – the report by Othmar Karas and Pervenche Berès, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 establishing a European Supervisory Authority (European Banking Authority); Regulation (EU) No 1094/2010 establishing a European Supervisory Authority (European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority); Regulation (EU) No 1095/2010 establishing a European Supervisory Authority (European Securities and Markets Authority); Regulation (EU) No 345/2013 on European venture capital funds; Regulation (EU) No 346/2013 on European social entrepreneurship funds; Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 on markets in financial instruments; Regulation (EU) 2015/760 on European long-term investment funds; Regulation (EU) 2016/1011 on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts or to measure the performance of investment funds; Regulation (EU) 2017/1129 on the prospectus to be published when securities are offered to the public or admitted to trading on a regulated market; and (EU) Directive 2015/849 on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purposes of money-laundering or terrorist financing (COM(2017)0536 – C8-0319/2017 – 2017/0230(COD)) (A8-0013/2019); – the report by Othmar Karas and Pervenche Berès, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1092/2010 on European Union macro-prudential oversight of the financial system and establishing a European Systemic Risk Board (COM(2017)0538 – C8-0317/2017 – 2017/0232(COD)) (A8-0011/2019); and – the report by Othmar Karas and Pervenche Berès, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2014/65/EU on markets in financial instruments and Directive 2009/138/EC on the taking-up and pursuit of the business of Insurance and Reinsurance (Solvency II) (COM(2017)0537 – C8-0318/2017 –2017/0231(COD)) (A8-0012/2019).

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has It is strange: ten years ago, I made two major reports on the causes and consequences of the greatest financial and social crisis with a Frenchwoman, Pervenche Berés. I ended the last parliamentary term with a report on the review of the troika in the programme countries with a Frenchman, with Li'm Hoang-Ngoc. And today we are presenting three reports together again, again with a Frenchwoman, Pervenche Berés, and these are your last reports.  At the same time, the Notre-Dame collapses. We could all welcome the reports today. Nevertheless, we are all sad. Because when the Notre-Dame collapses and not just burns, a part of us has collapsed, because we are Europe. We are part of the European Union. We have both always tried to overcome the ideological boundaries and put what we have in common. We have always tried to put substantive work above each other. That's why we were successful. And I would like to thank you, Pervenche, for your work on a day of sadness. One is just going under, the other is emerging. But I hope that the common strength of Europe can also rebuild the Notre-Dame. Maybe not as it once was. But we must never give up. And today's three reports, which we are making together, are already a milestone. I thank you and all the shadow rapporteurs for that.  We are creating new powers for supervisory authorities by pooling new supervisory and control powers against money laundering and terrorist financing, direct European supervision of certain cross-border financial transactions, less bureaucracy and better consideration of different sizes, risk profiles and complexities, more regulatory convergence through better instruments and new – no-action letters – and coordination groups, more consumer protection and the inclusion of sustainable risk factors, more involvement of supervisory authorities in decisions on third-country rules and greater democratic accountability to the European Parliament.  We strengthen governance through greater efficiency and faster decisions and avoidance of conflicts of interest, more tasks and powers of the Presidency, and a stronger role for the European Parliament. With a view to the new EU budget, we note that sufficient resources and staff must finally be made available, and we hope that the Member States will heed our call. And we are improving macro-prudential oversight to better identify systemic risks of all kinds in the future.  The reports are impressive. They are such a qualitative advance only because we have all worked together. May this cooperation, across ideological lines, also survive the election campaign and determine the policy of the next Parliament.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Mr Vice-President, dear Othmar Karas, this is indeed the second time that we have cooperated and I believe that we have cooperated as well as we did the first time. The Commission had put on the table a good, coherent proposal. If Member States want a capital markets union, then supervisory authorities must be strengthened. It may not be necessary to wait for the next crisis to realize that when you develop a market, it is better to have a gendarme to monitor that market, regardless of the quality of the players. Dear Othmar Karas, when you took responsibility for this report by my side, the child was indeed not doing very well. Some even considered him dead, some of the Member States rejoiced, but we saved him. We have ensured that Member States cannot use the pretext - which was politically useful to them - of progress in the fight against money laundering to be satisfied with it, but that they assume that real progress could not be made in the fight against money laundering without going ahead on the essentials, that is, that the European supervisory authorities are really able to exercise their competence. Perhaps less difficult, but I think it is a step that we must welcome, we have also made progress on the integration of a sustainability mandate. Supervisory authorities, whether in the banking, insurance or securities sectors, will have to examine the sustainability of the models implemented by the institutions. Similarly, in terms of consumer protection, we have taken an important step towards extending it in the area of banking and insurance on the basis of the powers that exist for the securities supervisory authority. I think that is a good step forward. Finally, at the initiative of some of our colleagues, we have introduced a coordination of mystery investigations, which is a good way to protect consumers. Moreover, for each of the authorities, we have improved a mechanism, in this case around the Banking Authority, to combat money laundering: this was normal and fair, until we had a truly independent authority and better coordination. In the area of insurance, we have taken reality into account. Too often, in this sector, shell companies are used to fail to respect consumer rights in other Member States: AEAPP will have stronger powers in this area and I can only welcome that. Finally, the securities authority, ESMA, will have more power to intervene with respect to data reporting providers and transactions in financial markets or benchmarks. However, the heart of the battle was obviously the question of governance. On this point, we have made useful improvements to decision-making to make it better informed, particularly in the event of a potential conflict of interest. The Chairs of the European Supervisory Authorities will be able to decide in the event of difficulties in reaching majorities and will be entitled to a tacit approval procedure for the convergence of supervision, the launch of procedures in the event of a violation of EU law and the settlement of disputes between the relevant national authorities in cross-border situations. Similarly, the authorities will be obliged to set up coordination groups when five relevant national authorities ask them to do so. But let us be honest, and I think, Vice-President, that you will be obliged to share my diagnosis: there is a certain hypocrisy on the part of the Council. He still wants to set up this capital markets union, which we know can be useful in financing the real economy, but when we want to strengthen that governance, we are told that we need to keep supervisory authorities that are "Member States driven institutions". There is a limit that will one day have to be crossed: let us collect what we have today, but let us know that this is only one step.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, the review of the European system of financial supervision is an important building block for achieving a genuine capital markets union. Therefore I am pleased that the co-legislators managed to find a political agreement on this very difficult package within just a few weeks during the trilogues in February and March. This allows this House to vote on this important legislative package still before the recess and brings much needed certainty for financial supervision in general and for the European supervisory authorities in particular. However, I must share the diagnosis that the level of ambition of the political agreement on a number of elements is indeed lower than initially proposed by the Commission.  Nevertheless, this result would not have been possible without the very constructive attitude from Parliament during the negotiations. Parliament has shown in those negotiations that it’s fully aware of the key role of the European supervisory authorities in achieving real market integration. So I would like to say thank you and congratulate the co-rapporteurs, Ms Berès and Mr Karas, for this work and for this achievement. And of course I hope for a positive vote in plenary. In my view this political agreement is a significant step towards complementing the Single Rulebook by more convergence of supervisory practices across the EU. Moreover, as a political agreement it is an important step forward to improve the EU’s anti-money laundering framework, broadly matching the ambition of the amended Commission proposal of September 2018. The new rules will confer new powers on the European Banking Authority in anti-money laundering supervision of the financial sector.  The three European supervisory authorities (the ESAs) have a key role in achieving convergence of supervisory outcomes and to ensure a level playing field for financial institutions and investors in the EU. Supervisory convergence is a precondition for a fully-fledged capital markets union. Truly integrated capital markets can only work properly to the benefit of the economy and consumers if rules are applied in a similar way in all Member States. I welcome that the agreement will equip the three ESAs with new and improved instruments to foster convergence in how the European financial sector is supervised. In particular, I hope that the peer reviews of supervisors will be more effective after this review. Moreover, newly established coordination groups will bring differences in supervisory approaches to light and will allow supervisors to cooperate in order to tackle prudential and level-playing-field concerns.  Finally consistent supervisory outcomes are also facilitated by some additional powers for ESMA, for direct supervision of certain benchmarks and reporting services.  I also welcome the strength and focus of the three authorities on consumer protection, on environmental, social and corporate governance considerations in finance, and on financial technology. Regarding governance, the agreement will contribute to more effective decision-making within the ESAs and I’m confident that the reinforcement of the chairperson’s role and powers will help to improve their governance. Finally, the legislators will equip the three ESAs with the necessary resources for the agreed tasks, even if industry funding originally proposed by the Commission was not agreed. I also welcome the political agreement reached on 21 March on the European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB) Regulation. The ESRB plays an important role within the European system of financial supervision in ensuring the stability of the financial system in the EU. This agreement will secure the further improved effectiveness of the ESRB.  The compromise found in political trilogues takes on board the majority of the amendments put forward by Parliament, as well as the Council. In particular, it requires the ESRB to carry out public consultations on a more systemic basis and strengthens its accountability. Furthermore, the compromise raises the visibility of the ESRB by giving a stronger role to the vice-chairs and the head of secretariat in the external representation of the ESRB. And as requested by Parliament, the new regulation also strengthens protection for whistle-blowers.  For the anti-money laundering (AML) part of the reform, I would like to hand over to my colleague Vĕra Jourová.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission considers it a priority to put in place all remaining building blocks for a Capital Markets Union and to complete the Banking Union. An important element of this picture is to have a working solution to many of the problems witnessed in the prevention and fight against money laundering and terrorist financing in the financial sector, given the serious cases we recently had in Europe involving European banks. As you know, this proposal of 2017 was further developed in September 2018 with a distinct element to better address anti-money laundering and redefine the role of the three supervisory agencies in this respect. We are very pleased that political agreement was reached on this very important file. The new rules will ensure that powers related to the prevention and mitigation of risks of money laundering in the financial sector will be centralised at the European Banking Authority. The new legal framework will strengthen its mandate for collecting, analysing and further disseminating information to ensure that all relevant authorities effectively and consistently supervise the risks of money laundering and that they cooperate and share information. The authority’s power to act where union law is breached has also been clarified and enhanced so as to guarantee that action can be taken immediately when anti-money laundering rules are broken at national level. This agreement required very intense work and a strong commitment by all the parties. I would like to thank the European Parliament and the Romanian Presidency for their efforts to reach an agreement in such a short timeframe. It is indeed reassuring to have seen the three institutions united to achieve improvements in this very important field.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Madam President, the European system of financial supervision has built upon a very specific institutional structure, which draws on a very broad membership, including national central banks, supervisors and EU institutions. In my view, it has also proven to be an efficient coordination platform and also an information hub for the monitoring of the risk from a EU-wide perspective, but there was a clear need to review the regulation in order to take into account the evolving context as well as recent institutional changes, in particular related to the Banking Union and the building up of the Capital Markets Union.  I agree with Commissioner Dombrovskis that we could have gone further with the change, but we have made, I think, true progress when it comes to enhanced scrutiny tools, democratic accountability, enhanced transparency and independence. They have been addressed during the negotiations as they eventually increased the impact of the ESRB actions.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, throughout the 11 years I have been a Member of the European Parliament, we have had numerous discussions about European common supervision of financial markets and also about the Capital Markets Union. If we want to create a prosperous Europe, we need to create a common capital market, and if we are about to create a common capital market and to lessen our financial risks, what we need is indeed a proper European financial supervision of different institutions. While I’m congratulating both of the rapporteurs for pushing the Member States further and about the significant steps that we have taken in this direction, unfortunately, I have to take up the issue that we are not yet in that place, and it is really hard and heart-breaking for me to see the resistance from the Member States on creating a proper European financial supervision. That should be the singular unit acting at Member State level and acting at the European level. I do not see the interest of different Member State cultures or different attitudes towards supervision, because here, if anywhere, the short-sighted national interest is not only a burial for Europe, but it is a burial for Member States themselves and the prosperity of our nations.

name: Neena GILL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. –Thank you, Madam President. I rise to speak on a report that has been long in hibernation and I had almost given up ever having an opportunity to speak on it, so my congratulations to the co-rapporteurs Ms Pervenche Berès and Mr Othmar Karas. These European supervisory authorities (ESA) reforms are an important step forward as a Single Rulebook with a consistent supervisory approach across the EU by the European supervisory authorities, and will, I believe, contribute significantly to well-functioning of the capital markets. But what is critical is that this reform will entrust the ESAs with greater consumer protection powers that will ensure that toxic financial products will be prohibited, and with additional responsibilities in their mandate on environmental, social and governance factors.  However, I am concerned that this exercise could become meaningless if we do not tackle the issue of money laundering with greater vigour, so I welcome the comments by Commissioner Jourová. European banks have lost EUR 20 billion in stock market value in the last six months, due to money laundering. Banking regulators need to show real ambition in addressing this. Given the powers to tackle this increase significantly, I am mindful that we still have not struck the right balance between the European level and the national level. This is, of course, a very fine line, but it does mean that the Member States have to move on from the status quo. That has been a recipe for a disaster and led to the last financial crisis. Banks and national supervisors must change their behaviour substantially, significantly, if the capital markets union is to become a reality, serving the real economy and EU savers.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, Mr Karas referred earlier to the report he had drawn up two or three years ago — perhaps even before — on the role of the troika in Greece, and I think this was an important report. However, the conclusions reached had no tangible effect, since the troika continued the same work in Greece and, at the same time, there was no compensation to the Greek people for what they suffered. For the damage that even Mr Dijsselbloem confessed to in a question I asked him and said that the measures taken in Greece saved, in essence, the euro and foreign banks and not the Greek people. It is certain that supervision is needed and that measures are certainly needed — as the Commission has said — to tackle money laundering. That's where the key is. We must tackle all these practices if we want to have democracy in the European Union, if we want the supervisory system to work seriously and if we really want to tackle this scourge called dirty money.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, as the Commissioners will know, progressive voices across Europe opposed the capital markets union (CMU) project, and they do so because it aims to sideline the problems in the EU’s banking sector by massively expanding the shadow banking sector and deregulating cross-border finance. This introduces in itself unacceptable new risks and dangers to financial stability.  But it has to be said that as far as this review is concerned, our Group thinks that the expansion of the powers of the EU supervisory authorities to accompany the deepening of the CMU is absolutely necessary. In some cases we acknowledge that the opposition of certain Member States to expanding the powers of the European supervisory authorities (ESAs) throughout this process has been based on legitimate concerns. But in other cases though, it was based on a reluctance to actually subject a shadow banking and funds sector that thrives on secrecy and on an almost total lack of oversight to any kind of supervision at all.  It’s this secrecy and lack of supervision that actually allows the mis—selling of financial products and money laundering to thrive. The boost in powers for the ESAs, therefore, is something I welcome, but the outcome of the negotiations is far from ideal and should have been, and could have been, more ambitious. We don’t just need to increase supervision. We need to reduce the massive volume of trade in complex financial products that takes place in the shadows and that threatens the financial stability of our entire economy.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her This report on the reform of European financial supervision shows the value of European institutions. The European Commission has presented a strong report and called for us to have joint supervision of European financial markets. The European Parliament, with a majority of Christian Democrats, Social Democrats, Liberals and Greens, has put forward strong proposals on how we can make progress, particularly with regard to consumer protection, money laundering and sustainable financial markets. A great deal of progress has now been made in this. But it is a sad reality that the Member States talk about it on Sundays when it comes to the banking union and the Capital Markets Union, but do the opposite on weekdays. That is why it is also the case that internal decision-making structures are still not European enough and that we therefore still have a long way to go towards a genuine capital markets union. It is quite bitter that the German Federal Government was on the wrong side of this.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Madam President, the European supervisors have been troubled by many issues – too little staff, too little resources, fragmentation, national demarcations – and Member States have been keen to sustain this troubled situation. I, therefore, commend the rapporteurs for having been able to defend the common European interests. Indeed, a common European supervision is essential for a common European capital market that allows us to share risks and make our economies more resilient. As with the banking package we discussed earlier tonight, the supervisory structures have to learn from past mistakes and to anticipate future developments, and one of these developments is Brexit. To what extent does Brexit trigger a race to the bottom? The answer very much depends on how much we are prepared to stand together. A stronger supervisory framework in Europe is therefore needed to cope with the consequences of Brexit, but also the emergence of fintech, new legislation on sustainable finance, the fight against money laundering and terrorist finance, and it’s good that the deal addresses these issues. But one word on sustainable finance, because I think there is a role the supervisors they need to play. We know that the risk of climate change and climate change policy are not priced in right now, not on the bank balance sheets, not on the balance sheets of insurances and pension funds and not by credit rating. And they will have an impact on the financial sector. Therefore, the supervisors should take the lead and take the mandate that had been given to them and to press on, making sure that these risks are priced in, and that the financial sector is prepared for the future in the short run, but also in the medium and long run. All in all, the new proposals are very timely and I congratulate the rapporteurs for striking a deal which addresses these challenges in the future and striking this deal under difficult circumstances.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for all your views and for today’s debate. As has been said, though the outcome is not as ambitious as I, and surely some of you, would have hoped for, I’m still convinced that this political agreement will help us to achieve more supervisory convergence in the future. It is a crucial step on our way to a genuine capital markets union, so once again, thank you to the rapporteurs, Ms Berès and Mr Karas, and let me ask you once again to lend your support to this outcome with your vote tomorrow.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to say to our European citizens, who may be watching us, that in this last week of the European Parliament alone, we are today dealing with 13 different reports from the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, which we will put to the vote tomorrow. Eight years ago, we began to respond to the global financial crises through a European supervisory system, and tomorrow, with the three reports, we are now adopting a comprehensive reform to make this system fit for the future. We are thus achieving another building block on the road to the completion of the Capital Markets Union and the deepening of economic and monetary union. This is good news for European citizens, the real economy, investment, jobs and growth in Europe. This shows that we are capable of action, that we are capable of solutions if we stick together. And I would also like to say at this moment that I would like to thank the predecessor for the report that I have adopted, Burkhard Balz, for the preparatory work and thank you all for the good cooperation.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank all of our colleagues for the tone they have adopted during this debate. Because, basically, Mr Vice-President, I believe that all our colleagues, regardless of the bench on which they sit in this Chamber, have shared some of the frustration of the co-staff. This Parliament wanted to support the Commission, it wanted to go very far and, finally, we ran into the Council wall. And in the Council, I hear incredible arguments that when you have a cross-border business - for example, if you issue prospectuses or if you have an internal model for your insurance company, that is, you are a large insurance company - it would be the competent national authority that, in the name of proximity and subsidiarity, would be in the best position to assess the risks. I think the Council is wrong. With Othmar Karas, we fought to snatch, piece by piece, what we got today. It will be up to our successors to examine this issue of the prospectus, to ensure that internal models do not remain under the sole gaze of a competent national authority, and to regulate, in the case of third countries, trading platforms or central custodians of securities. Perhaps the most important thing is, on the eve of the European elections, that our fellow citizens realize, when they seek the European spirit, when they seek this capacity to work together on European solutions for this market of ours, that it is in this Chamber, working hard under the impetus of the Commission's proposals, that we are most effective in the interests of the citizens.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 16 April 2019.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the joint debate on: – the report by Markus Ferber, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prudential supervision of investment firms and amending Directives 2013/36/EU and 2014/65/EU (COM(2017)0791 – C8-0452/2017 –2017/0358(COD)) (A8-0295/2018); and – the report by Markus Ferber, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the prudential requirements of investment firms and amending Regulations (EU) No 575/2013, (EU) No 600/2014 and (EU) No 1093/2010 (COM(2017)0790 – C8-0453/2017 – 2017/0359(COD)) (A8-0296/2018).

name: Markus FERBER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. In the European Union, we have set ourselves the goal of regulating the financial market, which is geared to the risk of the business model. This means that financial market regulation should be targeted and proportionate. Nevertheless, we have regulated investment firms for a long time as if they were banks. This is despite the fact that investment firms have a business model that differs in very much from that of banks, including the way they deal with risks. The regulation of investment firms was therefore not accurate for a long time. Correcting this is the aim of the new prudential framework for investment firms. As rapporteur, it was important to me that we take seriously the task of establishing a tailor-made supervisory regime. And that means that, contrary to what some colleagues and some Member States would have liked to see, we are not simply adopting the new rules from the banking package, but are really considering what a sensible framework for investment firms might look like. And in the end, it succeeded. We know three categories of investment firms. In the future, the supervisory regime will differentiate more according to size and systemic relevance. There are three categories for this: large, systemically important investment firms, which are still supervised by banking supervision; medium-sized but not systemically important firms whose capital isation obligations are measured by certain factors relating to the various traditional investment services, the risks of which are more accurately defined; and small and non-interlinked investment firms with a low risk profile and subject to a less stringent prudential regime. This three-stage classification is at the heart of the new supervisory regime and takes better account of the idea of proportionality, which we have already helped to make more prominence in banking regulation. However, the new framework for investment firms is not only more proportionate, but also more robust, especially with regard to the third-country regime. This is particularly important in the light of the United Kingdom's departure from the European Union, which has already been postponed twice and is planned. After all, more than half of all investment firms active in the EU come from the UK, and thus from a future third country. With the new set of rules, we are ensuring that British investment firms are subject to a strict regime after Brexit if they want to provide their services here in the European Union. We have broadened the list of equivalence criteria, strengthened the accountability of third-country companies to European supervisory agencies and given the European Commission more leeway in examining equivalence applications. In doing so, we have made the third-country regime more robust without fundamentally excluding certain MiFID services. At the same time, we have also strengthened the Commission's accountability to Parliament. So we also know what the Commission is doing. The investment firm review is thus an important building block for making the European financial market architecture ready for Brexit, strengthening proportionality and ensuring tailor-made regulation. Overall, I think we have reached a good and sensible compromise. And I would like to express my sincere thanks to all my shadow rapporteurs from the various political groups, to the Presidency of the Council and, of course, to the European Commission for the good and constructive cooperation.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Ferber, for his work. The review of the prudential framework for investment firms is an important part of the capital markets union (CMU) and banking union. It will set out a more proportionate prudential rule book for the vast majority of Europe’s small- and medium-sized investment firms. It should thus help these firms support the flow of investment in the Union and promote deeper and more integrated capital markets. The revised framework will also ensure that systemic firms remain subject to the existing prudential rule book alongside banks. Amongst these, the largest will come under the supervision of the single supervisory mechanism for their operations in the Member States that are part of the banking union. This will help ensure a level playing field in regulatory and supervisory conditions. Finally, some changes are introduced in how third-country investment firms can provide services to EU clients under the framework of equivalence set out in the Markets in Financial Instruments Regulation and Directive. These changes keep EU markets open to third-country firms while ensuring adequate transparency and safeguards for third-country operators offering key investment services on a significant scale and who also significantly enhance the role of ESMA in monitoring the activities of third-country firms in the Union. I wish to thank Parliament, and in particular the rapporteur, Mr Ferber, for reaching this outcome. The support demonstrated by Parliament –  not only by the rapporteur but also shadow rapporteurs – has been vital throughout the legislative process. I’m happy to say that the objectives and level of ambition of the Commission’s proposals are largely being achieved, thanks to the efficient and decisive approach adopted by Parliament. The Commission will now work on implementation of the revised rule book for investment firms at a similar pace, and I want to ensure that the benefits of the functioning of the capital markets are delivered in full and on time.

name: Mady DELVAUX
text: On behalf of the Group of President, I would first like to congratulate our rapporteur, Markus Ferber, for the way he has organised our work and defended our position in the trilogues. We have come up with good regulation. It was necessary and expected, as it is adapted to the specific profiles and risks that are inherent in the activities of different investment firms. It also corrects the situation by preventing some companies from enjoying national exemptions and from evading any regulation or oversight, as was the case before. The challenge was to divide the eleven types of investment firms identified by the European Banking Authority into three categories or three classes. The first includes the largest companies, those of systemic importance and still subject to banking regulation. The second includes most companies, about 6,000 of them, for which risks are calculated according to the so-called K factors. Finally, the third brings together small, non-interconnected businesses that do not pose a high risk and are therefore subject to very light regulation. It is a good compromise, both on capital requirements, which are proportionate while guaranteeing stability, but also on governance rules. The requirement for many companies to set up risk and compensation committees, and to ensure equal representation of women and men on these committees, is to be commended. I also welcome the level of transparency and reporting requirements and the introduction of non-discriminatory compensation policies. I also welcome the principle that this remuneration should not be given priority to short-term profitability, which I believe is an important step forward. Finally, I welcome the criteria that have been set for granting equivalencies and the increased role given to the European Banking Authority in the supervision of financial markets.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, first of all, I would like to express my sympathy to the French people for the damage suffered by France — and of course all humanity — by the destruction caused by the fire at Notre Dame, a monument of European heritage. The debate we are having today on prudential supervision of investment firms is important, because there is order in this matter and measures are being taken to ensure supervision. Supervision of particularly large investment firms, which may also involve systemic risk and rightly apply there rules that relate — and are, for the most part, similar — to the rules on banking control. In medium-sized enterprises there is a particular regulation, as of course in smaller ones. I think that is where we are right to take these measures. However, we must also take Brexit into account, because most businesses of this type are based in London. It needs regulation and attention to this issue.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this discussion and for the different points raised. The discussion shows that reform is welcome. Greater proportionality should help European investment firms prosper and drive more efficient capital markets for the benefit of savers, households and businesses.  Keeping some investment firms in the existing prudential framework, alongside banks, makes sense when these exhibit bank—like business models and risk features. An open but tightened equivalence regime for investment services adds value and choice for EU clients, while ensuring a level playing field for EU firms and avoiding the Union becoming excessively reliant on firms based in third countries for the provision of some key investment services, notably in the evolving context of Brexit.  I have taken good note of several of your remarks where further changes could have been considered. The new regime provides for an adequate implementation and phase-in period with the possibility to review the provisions in a few years’ time. I count on your continued support to ensure that the aims of the revised rules are achieved.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, i.e. a very warm thank you to those who were still brave and who took part in the debate. We were a few more shadow rapporteurs, dear Mady. I would have been pleased if some people had taken their time tonight. A very warm thank you to the Commission. I would just like to say that what we have now delivered from the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs this evening for reports and which we will put to the vote tomorrow will, on the whole, create a regulatory framework with which we can really see ourselves.
