I am sorry that, apart from the few who have worked intensively on it, there seems to be no public interest. We have put so much on the road, made Europe resilient and future-proof. That would have deserved more attention. But it seems that when you look at seemingly technical dossiers, where there is a lot of detailed work to be done, where you really have to dig yourself in and where you really have to deal with them intensively, it is less about the headlines of our newspapers than when something goes wrong somewhere. In the end, no one gets the solutions. And I'm eagerly waiting for someone to discover that we've forgotten or mishandled some little things. And I am pleased with the complaints that come about, how we have damaged the investment companies sector here. Nevertheless, I say that we can be proud of what we have achieved here in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs during this parliamentary term. We have done a great deal in all places, whether these are tricky things such as clearing houses, derivatives, but also supervisory structures and investment firms, in order to make our financial markets stable and secure. I hope that at least a few understand that.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 16 April 2019.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on failure to adopt a EU digital services tax (2019/2695(RSP)). I should inform Members that for this debate there is no catch-the-eye procedure and no blue cards will be accepted. There is a round of speakers for the political groups.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for organizing the debate today to speak about digital taxation and in particular the fate of the digital services tax, where a Council agreement has not been possible. On digital taxation, I know you have been vocally supporting our proposal and I would like to thank you for this.  Let me start my intervention by briefly recalling why the Commission presented an initiative on this issue on 21 March 2018. We did it because the underlying reasons remain valid and the problems that we are trying to fix remain unsolved. This has to be kept in mind while working on this issue during the upcoming months. After all it’s simple, international corporate tax rules are no longer adapted to realities of the modern global economy. They do not capture the benefits derived from digital services when there is no physical presence in the country.  The consequence of this inability to apply our current tax rules to these new realities is clear. Today profits from certain digital activities are barely taxed in the EU and this is unacceptable. It threatens the long-term sustainability of our public finances. It disrupts the conditions of competition for businesses in our single market and it undermines the fundamental principles of tax fairness.  This is why we have proposed two ways to ensure fair and equitable taxation of the digital economy.  Firstly, a structural proposal to reform the rules on corporate taxation so that profits are recorded and taxed where companies interact significantly with users via digital channels. This is a comprehensive solution.  Secondly, a more targeted proposal that responds to requests from several Member States for a provisional tax on the main digital activities that currently escape any form of taxation in the EU – the digital services tax. This is an interim solution to apply until the comprehensive solution is agreed.  As you know, Council discussions have mainly focused on this interim solution and we are obviously disappointed that Member States have not been able to reach a unanimous agreement on a proposal for the digital services tax, despite the fact that there was a large majority of Member States in favour. The failure to reach unanimous agreement on this file is largely explained by unanimity rule, according to which Council must decide unanimously on proposals in the area of taxation. As explained in this year’s communication on qualified majority voting, this is just another example of many tax initiatives where the unanimity requirement has hampered the progress needed to strengthen the single market and avoid its fragmentation. In today’s larger, modern and more integrated EU, a purely national approach to taxation no longer works and unanimity is not an effective way of decision-making. This is why we have launched the debate around this topic. In any event, I believe that the complex work that has led us to the near compromise on the digital services tax has not been in vain.  Firstly, it will provide a framework for our Member States which decide to move forward by adopting an interim solution at national level. Secondly, we will be able to examine the proposal on the table of the Council if the G20 and the OECD on the reform on the corporate tax system have reached no international agreement in 2020.  Moreover, the proposed digital services tax has the merit of having accelerated international discussion within the OECD and the G20 on the comprehensive solution. As you know, in March 2018 the OECD delivered an interim report in which it committed to reach a long-term consensus—based solution on the tax challenges arising from that digitalisation of the economy and the remaining [inaudible passage]. We strongly believe that the solution to tax and the digital economy must ultimately be a global one. We have to keep up the momentum for the G20 finance ministers discussions last year.  I will continue to work and engage with the international community and it will be important to coordinate the European efforts in the OECD.  Speaking with one voice will allow the EU to put more pressure on the discussions and better defend our interests. It will be important that in our efforts to modernise corporate tax rules, we avoid repeating mistakes from the past, creating new layers of complexity cannot be a way forward. We need to think of a system that is simple and future-proved. This should not patch the system but really reform it.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We are all aware of the urgency of this issue. While the effective corporate tax rate averages 23% in traditional sectors, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, it is around 9.5% in the digital sector. Tax rulings allow the big digital giants, internet companies, to pay only 1% tax. This is unfair, it is unfair, it creates distortions of competition within the internal market and it weakens small and medium-sized enterprises. As a Christian Democrat and as a supporter of the eco-social market economy, I cannot and will not put up with this. All the proposals to eliminate this injustice and unfairness are generally on the table by this Parliament and, in particular, by the Commission and Parliament, because we have already decided on a European digital tax on online income, because we have already decided to set up a digital permanent establishment. But what do we fail to do? We are failing because of the lack of political will in the Member States, we are failing in the tax havens within the European Union, and we are failing to veto the Council by unanimity. I therefore call on the Member States to put an end to your blockade. Stop the principle of unanimity so that we in the European Union finally get a digital tax, can implement the digital permanent establishment, become more globally capable of action and, in the digital age, it is enforced that tax must be paid where the added value is also made!

name: Paul TANG
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. Mr President, I will speak in Dutch. Many people still feel the crisis. Wages lag behind profits. Fixed work is under increasing pressure, while the bill of burdens and cuts has increased. Isn't it cynical that the companies that have grown to become the world's biggest – Apple, Facebook, Google, Amazon – pay the least tax? Does it not make sense that many Europeans – more than 35% of those surveyed in Germany, Sweden and Denmark – would have liked to have had a tax on digital turnover? Is it not cynical, then, that the proposal for such a tax on digital turnover has just failed these countries? Three-yard yes. There is therefore every reason to call into question the unanimity in the European Union on taxation. And yet. The proposal supported by the Social Democrats has had an effect. Firstly, the proposal has taken the United States to the negotiating table. That country is now prepared to discuss fundamental changes in the income tax in the OECD international negotiations. And fundamental reform is needed: the income tax comes from the beginning of the 20th century and is not up to globalisation and digitisation. Now Germany, the Netherlands and other countries must be prepared not to hide behind the idea of a minimum tax – which does not provide a substantial response to digitisation and globalisation and is merely a tool – but they must commit to a fundamental reform of the income tax. The European Parliament has already spoken out in favour of such a reform. There was a two-thirds majority for the CCCTB. Secondly, the proposal has led European countries to be tempted to propose a digital tax. France and Austria lead the way. Tributes to that. It puts pressure, necessary pressure on the international and European negotiations. I would like to call on other countries to come up with such a proposal themselves. Send the signal that cynicism will not prevail. Send the signal that the international negotiations will have to succeed. Send the signal that the world's largest companies must contribute fairly to the funding of schools, affordable housing and hospitals. Everyone must make a fair contribution, including the multinationals and the billionaires.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The tax practices of the Internet and tech giants in the European Union are well known: in 2014, for example, Apple paid just 50 euros in taxes per one million euros in profit. But Netflix and Amazon recently shot the bird: Both Internet companies paid no penny in taxes on their profits in the United States last year. Amazon even got a tax credit of 129 million, which meant it had a negative tax rate, with a profit of 11 billion. Nobody understands that anymore!  Unfortunately, against this background, it says a great deal about the state of the European Union that no agreement has been reached on a digital tax. The legitimate attempt to transform common tax law into the 21st century has failed for the time being. This attempt is by no means a demonisation of Internet companies, as the German Finance Minister Olaf Scholz once claimed, but about tax justice. This is what people expect of us: that companies and the wealthy make their fair share of social development and pay taxes accordingly.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her What we are seeing here is truly a tragedy for the European Union. The European institutions have worked, the European Commission has addressed the justice deficit in the taxation of digital companies with a clear proposal. Parliament has included this proposal. There was a very broad majority in this House. Basically, everyone was in favour of serious taxation of digital companies. The whole thing has failed in the Council.  But why did it fail in the Council? Because some tax havens, some Eurosceptic countries, supported by the grand coalition in Germany, have put this proposal on hold. And Olaf Scholz is wrong to believe that he can reassure Mr. Trump by refusing a European solution and negotiating at OECD level instead.  This is an issue that all voters should take a close look at. The grand coalition in Germany is responsible for the fact that we did not get the digital tax, and I hope that many voters will take this into account when deciding.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I am very pleased that this disastrous idea of introducing another tax has collapsed. This is a victory for taxpayers. Every penny snatched from you who waste taxpayers' money, live out of it and throw it pointlessly around the world is a victory for taxpayers. The only fair system is one in which people who have earned an income retain that income for themselves, not one in which others take it away from them under duress. In fact, it is also most beneficial for the economy when this money stays with those who have earned it, because they know how to earn it. If I hear once again that you want more money for hospitals, for schools, etc., you are running out of money for hospitals and schools, you are going to have some nonsensical programmes like Erasmus+, then you will have more money for hospitals and schools. Put an end to nGO funding programmes around the world, africa, Asia, etc., you will have money for schools for European taxpayers. Put down stupid programs, and then go deeper into taxpayers' pockets.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank honourable Members once again for their dedication, work and support on this project. We of course regret that unanimity could not be found in the Council on the digital services tax. However, the work on the file is not lost but will provide a framework for Member States which may decide to make progress on their own by legislating at national level. We can return to the Union debate if no international agreement can be reached on a comprehensive solution at OECD level.  Moreover, we are pleased to see how the digital services tax proposal, which almost reached a compromise in the Council, triggered a debate at international level on the tax challenges posed by the digital economy. So Europe is shaping this debate. The OECD and G20 negotiations on how to reform the corporate tax framework will be extremely important. Therefore, we need to continue the work and focus our efforts on this. The Union’s participation in such discussions must be coordinated. We have budgetary and social responsibilities that are unique to Europe. The challenge is twofold. Firstly, we must collectively ensure that our public finances are sustainable, and, secondly, we also need to ensure a fair distribution of the tax burden.  We can be proud of what has been achieved together on this file, but we are also aware that the work is unfinished. We also believe that the blocking of the digital services tax by a few Member States in the Council, and previous similar experiences, should be seen as a wake—up call concerning the need for the Union to gradually move towards qualified majority voting on tax matters. The decision—making process on tax matters needs to be resolved.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. I draw Parliament's attention to an outrageous, outrageous case in Romania. The mayor of Korond, a municipality in Szeklerland, was fined €97,000 for displaying the name of the institution in Hungarian alongside the official Romanian inscription "town hall" or "hôtel de ville" in addition to the official Romanian inscription. I express my community's dissatisfaction, the judgment is disproportionate, it is a disremity for European values. It goes against what is permitted by law and is required by international conventions ratified by Romania. Such an incredible decision increases tension, mistrust of mainstream society and justice. The majority-minority relationship needs to be settled, dialogue and solutions are needed in Romania. Retaliation does not serve the interests of the Romanian or Hungarian communities or the general interests of the country.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, health is a very important concern of European citizens in all Eurobarometers and everyone expects the European institutions to do more. Important progress has been made in this parliamentary term: better legislation on medical devices, progress on the evaluation of medical technologies, the foundations for a more ambitious health programme and the largest health research programme, in which pediatric cancer will play a very important role, is being prepared. The election campaign is a good opportunity to discuss and see how we can do better in the future at European level in the field of health and be more ambitious in the period ahead. We will need to fight cancer better, reduce inequalities, fight intra-hospital infections, ensure better access to innovation, especially in medicines, and prepare our health systems for the digital revolution.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Europe and Ukraine are also facing decisive elections. In May, it will be decided where to go next. I hope that Europe will have leaders who care about Christian European roots, family and European indigenous national minorities. And on Easter Sunday, Ukraine will have the second round of the presidential election. Easter means resurrection, hope, and faith. I trust that the President will be elected democratically according to the will of the electorate, and that Ukraine will finally embark on the path of the rule of law in Europe, that corruption will be eradicated and that real reforms will begin. My hope is that Ukraine will have a president who does not divide citizens into first and second class, who respects the constitutional rights and international commitments that have been acquired. I also hope that after the elections, ethnic tensions will be eased, enemy image creation, veganism and anti-Hungarian attacks will cease. Extremists are contained and the president-elect defends the rights of national minorities in the country, including Hungarians in Transcarpathia.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, in the last plenary session of the 2014-2019 legislature we are once again discussing Brexit. A new extension in extremis, agonizing. It is imperative to criticize the House of Commons, which has been unable to take a recognizable position. Just as we must support the unity of action shown by the European Union by protecting the rights of citizens as a priority: of the British in the European Union and of the Europeans in the United Kingdom. This is particularly sensitive in some regions with intensity of economic and trade relations with the United Kingdom, such as the Canary Islands. Five million British visitors a year who were pending the visa waiver that we have managed to approve in this European Parliament. Thirty thousand Britons residing in the Canary Islands, five thousand Canaries residing in the United Kingdom. And transactions of sensitive products, such as banana or tomato, that required legal certainty. But I hope that the debate will clarify at once that, if there is an extension, we have the right to ask a question and get an answer: An extension for what?

name: Răzvan POPA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is little time until the end of Parliament's current parliamentary term, and it is regrettable that, in these last weeks of work, the European forum and representatives of the Commission have already entered the electoral campaign. And the target of this election campaign, involving parties and politicians at European level, has become Romania. I find this unacceptable. Today we had a debate with a predictable development, Romania being again unfairly criticised by the same voices already recognised. Romania has chosen to behave with dignity in the face of these attacks, not to respond with the same currency, even if the double measure is obvious. We do not comment on corruption cases in other European countries, nor on the sovereign right of Member States to decide their legislation in the field of justice. Disturbing is that these criticisms either do not refer to concrete elements or concern decisions that do not actually exist in Romania, which is not normal. I call clearly and firmly to an end to these approaches. The election campaign must not end up affecting the image and construction of the European project - a positive and necessary project in which citizens believe and expect solutions.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Madam President, some time ago we learned that in Spain, the School Commission on Gender Equality concluded that almost two hundred fairy tale stories are sexist. It is a surprise to me that something like this can be encountered, because generations of European children have grown up listening in a nice, pleasant children's way about what the right values are in life, the values of good and evil, the values. who simply educate the character of a person who can then stand up for what is right in life and what is wrong in life. I think that there is a very strange situation going on here, and we should be able to fence off against such things in our collegiating Member States, because it is wrong for us to dictate what children should listen to and what is not. It's up to the parents to decide.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Support for membership of the European Union is quite high throughout the Union. Over 65 percent of Swedes think we should be involved. At the same time, the same opinion polls show that a majority of citizens do not trust Europe, do not trust us to help them deal with the problems they have in everyday life. What these two figures tell us together is that we must immediately present a plan to improve the way this Union operates, to regain the confidence of its citizens. If we do not do that, this Parliament will not only be filled with extremists on two sides – which we do not want in this Parliament next term – but support for membership will also decrease. Then we have serious problems. Now we have a month. Now we must show the citizens that we hear what they say, that we are taking it on board, are prepared to do something about it and are therefore worthy of their confidence.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: Mr President, at the end of my term of office, I would like to speak in Dutch or Flemish in my final speech. I am Catalan and the Spanish Government does not protect the free use of my language. But Belgium has three languages: French and German – I have spoken those languages since I was a child – and Flemish, which I have tried to learn a little in my time here. I thank my teacher Sandra Peeters for the tremendous patience and skill she has used to make progress with me. This is my tribute to European pluralism, in the hope that Catalan will soon become an official language. Thank you all, including you, Madam President.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, one of the themes of this European legislature, which we finished this week, has been Catalonia.  Many of you will have discovered a country that wants to decide its future by voting, which wants to self-determination; you will also have seen how the police have attacked voters, how they have imprisoned our legitimate representatives for organising a referendum, and how they are now being judged as criminals.  But as long as you discovered this, we Catalans discovered something else: we discovered the most hypocritical face in Europe. While most were silent, as Juncker received awards in Spain and while Timmermans saw no problem with democracy and fundamental rights in Spain, our disenchantment with Europe multiplied.  But if you want Catalan independence to be disengageed from Europe, I tell you that you will not get it, that we will not do you this favor. We are not the ones who have disassociated ourselves from the project of European values: it is you.  So we will return, and more strongly, to restore Europe from the rights and freedoms that they should never have abandoned.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Madam President, the Commission plans to allocate EUR 13 billion over the next five years for an EU defence fund: a euphemism for a European army. And this at a time when public services in countries like Ireland are stretched to breaking point. Military neutrality is an important plank of Irish foreign policy. Sinn Féin will oppose increased Irish contributions to an EU budget that is concentrating on developing a war machine. Instead, we will defend Irish neutrality in order to save our taxpayers millions, keep our citizens safer, safeguard our international reputation and allow us to play a positive role in peace-building across the world. Last week, Fianna Fáil and Fianna Gael rejected a Sinn Féin motion that will allow the Irish people the chance to enshrine neutrality in our Constitution. This was just another missed opportunity to spare us the indignity of funding and implicitly supporting the ever-hastening moves towards an EU army that all too many in this House pursue. Sinn Féin will play no part in these games. We will fight for Irish neutrality all day, every day.

text: – A Uachtaráin, d’fhéadfadh cinneadh Choiste AGRI vótáil ar son chomhchlaonadh na n-íocaíochtaí aonair feirme méadú €50-100 milliún a chinntiú do Thoghcheantar Lár-Tíre agus an Iarthuaiscirt faoi dheireadh na bliana 2026. name: Martin SONNEBORN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which As a member of the Committee on Culture, Youth, Youth, Cooperation and Culture, I would just like to recommend an action film to you. And one more word to the British, who are now probably part of the EU until Halloween: if you hand over Julian Assange to the US, then you can have your stupid Brexit immediately, because of me as hard as possible.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Biggest disease of the European Parliament is legislative diarrhoea. We are releasing more than five hundred documents a year from this House, that is, more than one a day. No one in this House is able to read all this, much less anyone is able to read it outside Parliament, because people still have to make bread, not read everything that the European Parliament writes out. Another consequence of this disease is that we vote in an incredibly hasty, messy way. Votes are sometimes conducted at a rate of less than two seconds per amendment. In practice, the presidents of the deliberations admit that they do not look at the whole room, but at the leaders who sit in front. There is therefore, in fact, a vote in place of other Members, which is unacceptable, because the mandate of an MEP is inalienable. You can't give your voice to others or presume that everyone is voting like the whole group.  In connection with all these irregularities, I have asked experts to draw up a report on abuses of the rule of law in this parliament. After translating it into English, I will send it to all Members. I hope that they will be rectified in the next term of office.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, children’s rights are not a soft nor a small issue. They are a serious issue. As founder of the Intergroup of Children’s Rights and now European Parliament coordinator on children’s rights, we together have been the driving force for putting children at the heart of the EU internal and external action. A permanent body of the Parliament acting as a focal point, mainstreaming children’s rights, was much needed, and my priority has been to prevent and combat all forms of violence against children, to protect migrant children and to increase child participation. We have come a long way. We are in close partnership with the Council of Europe and the UN family to strengthen cooperation to protect children globally, and in this House we have just launched both the economy and childhood global index on child sexual violence and the ‘act to protect children in conflict’ campaign by the Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Children and Armed Conflict. For the next mandate, I call on the Commission to adopt a new child rights agenda, to review the ePrivacy, the Audiovisual Media Service Directive, GDPR and other acts on the sexual abuse of children, to create a safe internet for kids. I call on all candidates to join our pledge to become a child rights champion and to commit to promote the children’s rights mandate.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, the Turkish occupation of Cyprus continues and is a crime against the European Union. But when we put it out five years ago, in this Chamber, very few people paid attention. When Erdoğan went ahead and crushed human rights in Turkey itself and imprisoned anyone who disagreed with him, there began to be more people who paid attention, but some still found reasons to support him. As we speak, however, in the Eastern Mediterranean the Republic of Cyprus is trying to exploit its energy reserves for the benefit of the European Union. I think the time has come and we will all be judged in practice. Are we going to support the Republic of Cyprus and European interests in a common foreign and defence policy or are we going to find reasons to support Turkey again? While the Turkish occupation of Cyprus continues, Europe remains mutilated. In politics we are judged on our insight. Let us finally put Europe itself first and for all, not everything else.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Madam President, I thank you for giving me the floor. Because in all my speeches in this legislature since March 1st I have always referred to life and life-related issues. But today I invoke a right, which is the right to die worthily. Precisely because there has been a very important debate on euthanasia in the Spanish State. A debate because a person, the husband of a woman with a very serious illness, for assisting her in a dignified death had to go to court, and may have committed a crime. A very serious situation. Because if that person lived in Belgium, he'd have different rights. Or if you lived in one of the few Member States that recognise euthanasia. I would like to ask the Commission at the moment, and also the outgoing Parliament, to open a debate in Europe on euthanasia. In all Member States and as a European issue.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. As the EP election eds up, we are talking more and more about the possible involvement of extremist political parties. It is not enough to talk about this subject on a principled level. We also need to look at how one or other of our member parties here is helping to legitimise extremism at home. Unfortunately, I can also cite my country, Slovakia, as an example. There, Smer, a member party of the EPP, Most-Bridge and a member party of the Socialists, formed a coalition with a nationalist party, the Slovak National Party. The result is that the two epp and socialist member parties, which are problematic in themselves, are completely in love with the nationalist partner. Corruption has intensified in the country. That's what many believe holds the coalition together. The rule of law has sunk to the point where journalists have been murdered, and now a law has been passed banning the singing of the national anthems of other countries, such as EU Member States, and legal persons who break the ban can be fined up to EUR 7 000. This is unacceptable, honourable European Commission, action must be taken.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, because we are approaching the end of this parliamentary term, I would like to note that, against the differences in political approach between us, the European Union project is ready to go further and move towards a Europe of cohesion. I note and appreciate that, for the first time in the history of the European Union, cohesion policy is at the forefront. Thus, in the 2021-2027 budget, the portfolio responsible for cohesion policy will have the largest amount allocated, i.e. EUR 373 billion, and Romania, Bulgaria and Greece have foreseen an increase of more than 10% in the cohesion funds allocated compared to the current amounts. It is an important signal to the citizens of the countries that later joined and where the so-called 'multi-speed Europe plan' was not received very well. In this way, I welcome the European Commission's initiative, which is a positive signal that, despite all the discussions in recent years on the future of Europe, we are determined to live and develop together, with as little differences as possible between Member States. Europe together is and must remain our objective.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, let me first begin by opening my speech to express France's participation in the cultural tragedy that is now taking place in Paris. Notre-Dame is Europe's cultural heritage, and I firmly believe that the French firefighters will be able to handle the situation, even if it does not look very welcoming. The European Union faces many challenges, be it Brexit, terrorism, of course, population eviction or plastic infestation, but in my opinion the most serious issue is climate change. We need to adapt to this climate change, it is actually a key threat to our future and the incompetence on this issue can really backfire on us. We must retain water in the landscape and thus fight drought. Access to the countryside must change from farmers, from, of course, to us who live in that country. I would also like to draw attention to the threat of emissions. The Czech Republic has one of the most polluted air in Europe. We should start on our own. Only together can we meet these challenges, whether through European resources or innovation. I firmly believe that we will be able to handle this.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is the last one minute speech of this parliamentary term, a parliamentary term that I have lived through with great intensity, always trying to represent my country to the best of its kind. I have spent many hours in this plenary and I am glad that I have done so, just as I am proud to have been one of the most present and productive Members of Parliament.  From this week I will be campaigning to proudly bring to the 1784 municipalities of southern Italy the idea of Europe that has matured in recent years in me. A Europe community of peace for all, but also the ambition of the need for a United States of Europe, and I will do so in a beautiful, but difficult and complex territory, a territory that deserves to be redeemed by a ruling class finally worthy of the name, a territory tired of the usual political politicians who delude citizens with embarrassing clientele promises. I appeal to the voters: let us respect our land, let us raise the bar of legality in this election campaign, let us stop these methods of hoarding consensus, based on the concept of do ut des. Long live the European Union, long live Italy, long live southern Italy.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. As a citizen of my country, I am saddened to find that the deteriorating situation of the rule of law in Romania has been on the EP's agenda for the third time since October last year. As a Hungarian from Romania, I must also draw attention to the systemic anti-minority and anti-Hungarianism, which is also a serious violator of the rule of law, on which the Commission's reports are deeply silent. In concrete form, I demand the unconditional release of the political prisoners of the nationalist, post-communist Romanian regime, which is intertwined with the secret service, because of their Hungarianness– István Beke and Zoltán Szőcs – and the immediate abolition of the €100,000 wrongful fine imposed on Mayor Mihály Katona for the use of the Hungarian language! In order to resolve such cases of de-government, I call for the effective support of Parliament and the Commission.
